output: Mr. President, first, I would like to congratulate Mr. Sibep on the work done, because his report includes many of the concerns expressed in this
The focus is on these issues crucial for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem for the countries of Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the considerations outlined in the opinion report, of which I served as rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture, in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate commodity prices, an aspect in which the current times also seem to me very important to highlight, so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action likewise mentioned in the Agriculture Committee’s report, and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be voted on tomorrow reflects, however, a proposal made by the Agriculture Commission to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose again to Parliament when, in the coming months, the Commission publishes its communication on adaptation to climate change.

It seems to me that after the Solidarity Fund was established—created originally to alleviate the losses caused by climatic disasters—it is time for us to consider an instrument that acts proactively and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of those climatic catastrophes.
Atlético de Madrid, its fans, and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
However, the case extends beyond the particular, as those federative bodies increase the penalties for those who resort to the ordinary justice system.
This medieval conception, this funnel law, is incompatible with the law, with European institutions, from which we must react.

And we will inevitably bring it about, for those medieval lords, arbitrary with the rope and the knife, must align themselves with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.
Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon, and so too is the activity of serious organized crime. Therefore, measures must be proportionate and must be tackled effectively.

I have taken good note of the responses given to the pertinent questions. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a delicate matter, but it is no less certain that it is absolutely inexcusable to construct, form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some who find terrorism a bit distant, individual guarantees are of greater concern.
I am concerned with both the individual and the collective. And it is absolutely necessary that we begin where we can.
If we have begun with air transport, where companies already have that data, let’s start there.

Let's demand guarantees, let’s see what the scope of application is, let’s begin with international transport relationships and, mind you, we’ll have to continue with the domestic ones because terrorists often do not come from outside, but rather from within.
Let the United States and the others be asked; that is how it is, and that is how we must frame it.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the committee for having presented this proposal.
I believe it is a positive proposal that will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as speakers before me have pointed out, this Parliament has the obligation to ground proposals that are very generous and very altruistic on the part of the Commission.

The reality is that there is a national reality encompassing 27 countries with different legal systems and vastly different languages, which necessitates that in each of those countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the matter of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset has just pointed out and as previous speakers have noted, it is important that the recognition of these national specializations does not lead to an increase in costs, that rates be uniform, and that governments eventually assume this additional cost.
But there is a topic that also arises, which is the topic of translations.
Specifically within the European Union, we do not have a common language.
In the 27 countries, vastly different languages are commonly spoken; indeed, in some countries, such as the commissioner’s, multiple languages are spoken, and we live with this reality.
And from a legal perspective, moreover, we encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
In the Legal Committee, the Legal Committee has proposed, for example, amendments regarding the authentication of records, of documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At this moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in different countries of the European Union, which should be complementary to this report.
Ultimately, I believe the commission has done well in presenting this report.
The speaker has done a magnificent job, and I believe we have all striven to craft a legislative proposal that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing the rights of citizens.
rights and starting from the foundations of the reality of a union that is being built, which has different national legal systems and different levels of access to electronic communication.

Thank you, President. A large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting decisions and agreements that the European Union’s Council of Ministers for Agriculture will adapt between today and tomorrow regarding this economic assessment.

the CAP, because it is not a simple revision, but will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms. This cutback proposed by the European Commission on direct payments goes ahead.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament’s opinion to have some impact on the negotiations being held by the Union’s agriculture ministers.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not possible.

not due to a lack of resources within the spending ceiling of the CAP, but rather due to an absolute absence of political will to provide the Community budget with that necessary structural development.
Pilar. Do you want to liberalize the markets?
Certainly, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At this moment, the European Union is determining the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would particularly like to make reference to vulnerable sectors such as sheep farming, cattle farming, and tobacco cultivation, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this assessment.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep sector, no longer request assistance, but simply want to exit the market with dignity, because they have calculated that the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

Therefore, abandoning production is the only way out we leave for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because consumers will continue to consume and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
Parliament should issue a considered opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I would like to express my appreciation from here to the President of the Committee on Agriculture for the efforts made by Mr. Pérez to ensure that Parliament is heard and not dismissed in such a clear and overt manner by the Council and the Commission as has been the case until now.
Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to join the congratulations of the rapporteur, Mr. Capula Santos, for his magnificent work.
I believe you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I believe that at this stage of the debate, it is important to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are required for sectors in difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions do not apply to all sectors.
It is important to remember that we have sectors experiencing genuine difficulties.
The Common Agricultural Policy does not have to be the problem, but the solution. And for that, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and champion rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified, and that market instruments should be reviewed.
But that does not mean dismantling them.
If we do this well, we will be laying the foundation for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be undermining the activity of many European farmers.
We are presented with a plan highly anticipated by the fruit sector, not only due to the difficulties it faces, but also because of the concerning decline in consumption.
We are confronted with a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also advocate for full community funding.

I do not agree with parental involvement in co-funding, because what always happens will occur. Parents who can contribute financially will see their children consume fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it must be a community-funded plan to ensure its distribution is homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize the need to focus on educational measures.

It is not merely a matter of a student eating an apple, but knowing what type of apple they are eating. To understand its nutritional properties and to comprehend the beneficial effects that such fruit has on their health and development.
Of course, these must be products with all quality guarantees, prioritizing, if possible, seasonal fruits and, whenever feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the commissioner, we will notice immediately. Of course, for the present and future health of our children and their current education.

But I also believe it is very important for the horticultural sector—a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage. For thanks to it, we can enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worthwhile to invest and support this plan for the distribution of fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I believe the budget falls a little short because I advocate for full Community financing of a plan as ambitious as this one.
Yes, thank you, President. I request that you not include these first words in the ailing time machine, please, because my questions are very important.
My first words are to add my voice to the message of condolence expressed by this chamber to Mrs. Clam and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now I begin.

I congratulate the speakers because with these two proposals, we are taking a qualifying step toward a common immigration policy, and we are entering the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach we advocate.
The overarching framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal emigrants should be extended to the greatest number of workers.
That is why socialists are requesting that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called Blue Card offers an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
opens a unique door to 27 labor markets.
However, through this door should not only enter highly qualified workers,
Therefore, Commissioner, we expect the Commission to present its proposals relating to the other occupational categories shortly.
Honorable members, we must combat brain drain.
This blue card should not become a passport that encourages a drain of vital human resources from developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we want to ensure that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in their country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly 300,000 highly skilled Europeans emigrated to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything possible to keep them at the European House.
Madam Vice President, do you believe that the closeness or distance of candidates to voters has to do with the level of participation in the European elections?
European. Do you agree that a state of 45 million inhabitants should have only one electoral district for elections to the European Parliament?
What can the Commission do to ensure that states with larger populations have constituencies closer to their citizens?
Excuse me, but I have not heard that the Vice President has responded to my questions.
Thank you very much, Madam President. You have provided me with considerable information on the topic I raised, and I am grateful for that detailed information.
I believe the new phase of the Commission is important, and above all, the Bamako project, a center of the European Union concerning immigration.

I understand it has just been launched, which is likely very early, but the question I pose to the committee is, should that Bamako-Bali project on immigration yield positive results, does the committee believe it possible to extend this experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I acknowledge the response on behalf of Mr. Yañez, but I must say to Mr. Misel, that his actions, words, and gestures are very necessary in direct and relevant contact.
truly with the Cuban democratic opposition, to fulfill the Council’s priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favor of freedom.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express my group’s strongest condemnation of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by anyone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the manner in which this heinous murder was committed—we know it now—a 13-year-old girl who is raped and subsequently accused of adultery, and five men, if they can even be called men, hasten to stone her and prevent anyone from attempting to save her, in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, coupled with the acts of piracy that this year along the coasts of Somalia have reached a level of nearly 100 ships seized, constitutes a humanitarian situation that is absolutely unacceptable.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit atrocities,
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions have we been presented with such a clear situation, one that imposes obligations upon us.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive here within this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it will be possible, but I am certain that it must be done and that intervention is required swiftly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that have been presented at the last minute, which were not negotiated previously.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this will be the beginning of greater concern from the European Union regarding this type of humanitarian issue and the condemnation of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the speaker and the presenters who have preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this directive proposal from the European Parliament and the Council.
This concerns the recognition that armaments and ammunition, too, are within the internal market, albeit with a series of limitations.
These are not standard goods; they are not candies nor entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Certainly, there are limitations inherent in the treaty itself, article 30 and article 296, which confer significant responsibilities on the States in the matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not preclude States from being obligated to comply with safety regulations and having the right to enforce them when their own security is endangered.

The work carried out in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the committees of opinion that have collaborated with it in accordance with the Council, under the expert direction of the Policy, Ms. Ruiz, has been very positive.
I believe the text we present today is a rather balanced text.

Basically, despite the fact that on paper they appear to be many amendments, today we are limited to a single amendment, which is amendment 63, which embodies the spirit of compromise. Within that amendment, one can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow for the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Tubón has highlighted that this is related to other international texts.

For example, the adoption this same month of the Oslo Convention, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the prohibition of cluster munitions, also the convention on limitations of anti-personnel mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even regulations of the European Union aimed at limiting the use of weapons.

I believe our model is not one of the free circulation of arms at any time, but rather of a regulated market, controlled by the States and also, from now on, by the institutions of the European Union themselves.
Madam President, Commissioner. This proposal emerged from the committee more than a year ago with truly very ambitious objectives.
And during this time, financial upheavals have occurred worldwide that appeared poised to sink these measures. But ultimately, a balanced agreement has been reached that was not achieved.
It does not satisfy almost anyone fully, but it is a good agreement, one that maintains the final objectives, yet makes the means to achieve them more accessible to businesses.

Therefore, we must express our sincere gratitude and congratulate the speaker, Ms. Doyle, the speakers from the other political groups, and the French presidency in particular, because their work has ensured a positive outcome for everyone.

I am confident that in the near future circumstances will allow us to be far more ambitious, and that other countries will also join this crusade to combat climate change, which we so earnestly wish to carry out in Europe.

Thank you, President. Commissioner, this was a good proposal, as it emerged from the committee, not only because of the sulfur reductions, but also because of its new Article 7b, which required suppliers to reduce sulfur.

gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it resolved the long-standing problem of vapor pressure for gasoline blends with bioalcohol in countries like mine, which experience warm summers.
Precisely this did not pass the filter of the vote in the Environmental Committee, and this concerned many of us.

Today, we have an agreement on the table that softens the application of Article 7bis and reinstates the vapor pressure waiver, while, of course, tightening the conditions for accessing the exception.
And as with the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone 100%, but it is nevertheless acceptable to all.

I wish to thank Mrs. Corbyn for her excellent work, for the responsiveness she has shown in resolving issues, as well as Mr. Turmes and, of course, the French presidency, who have also demonstrated considerable effectiveness here.
As the report states, according to 2007 estimates, Zimbabwe has a population of 12 million, nearly half of whom are experiencing hunger.

Life expectancy is 36 years or more, and only 40% of the country’s teachers are working, with just one-third of students attending class; consequently, Mugabe is not only destroying the present, he is destroying the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights are also commonplace.
Zimbabwean human rights defenders have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detentions, arrests, and torture.
The legislation introduced by the Government severely restricts freedoms of expression, assembly, movement, and association.
I would like to cite several of them, as the Government has introduced increasingly repressive regulations, which have been used against these activist human rights defenders.

For example, the law on access to information and protection of privacy, used by the Government to effectively silence journalists. The public order and security law, which has severely limited the freedom of assembly and hundreds of

Human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily detained, and also the Law on Voluntary Organizations of a Private Nature, reinstated in 2002 by the Government and allegedly used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my mother tongue, Basque—Euskera—which is not an official language in this Chamber, “Mugabe” means without limit. A fitting epithet for this individual.

The dictator of that African country is not merely one more on the extensive list of dictators that, unfortunately, we count on this planet, but I would not dare to say that he occupies one of the positions in the top ten of international dictators.
I believe that in the EU we must do everything possible to ensure this individual leaves and spends the rest of their days seated before a human rights tribunal.
We wish Zimbabwe a happy year 2009 without Mugabe.
We have a draft resolution on Nicaragua regarding which several aspects must be considered.
First, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this casts a shadow over the electoral result of November 9th.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned with resolving some of the problems that erode human rights in Latin America.
specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, access to potable water, and the lack of land tenure for indigenous populations.
Therefore, when examining the case, we must distinctly differentiate the two aspects.

On one hand, we must stimulate human rights and we must defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights. And on the other, we must encourage the Nicaraguan government in its function of assistance to the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must guarantee that the opposition can exercise its function; we must oppose fraud; but, and we must defend the work of NGOs.
However, a balanced outcome must be achieved.
The Socialist Group has presented several proposals for oral amendments, seeking to steer the final text toward a more balanced approach with respect to the claims of…

violations of fundamental rights, with regard to the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations and with regard to the number of municipalities in which the effect has produced some form of derogation.

In summary, we want to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going so far as to place the government of Nicaragua in a difficult position to continue fulfilling its function of supporting the most vulnerable segments of society.
Regarding the situation created in Nicaragua due to attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

It is unnecessary to recall here now either Soy la América, or Ernesto Cardenal, or Carlos Mejía Godoy, or Jarquín, or Sergio Ramírez, or so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November of 2006, Mr. Ortega requested and democratically obtained from the Nicaraguan people what he termed a new opportunity.
We now know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrary actions, nepotism, and corruption have become entrenched in government institutions, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9th elections.

Previously, very serious decisions had been adopted, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of certain opposition parties, threats and intimidation of civil society members, journalists, and media outlets.
President Ortega described the governments of the European Union as flies swarming over filth and characterized the external aid Nicaragua received as crumbs.
He soon understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to dispense with that development assistance.

As we prepare to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua should know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

but for us, the insistence on respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy in sum, is a condition to which we do not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua especially benefit from it.
Until November 9th of last year, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.
As on previous occasions, that electoral process has been challenged from the perspective of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and curses being uttered.
demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been experiencing.

Two political parties have been unable to present their candidacies in the local elections, which is unacceptable because it restricts the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.
On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

regarding the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought as many as 17 organizations of social movements before the courts, concerning the persecution of independent journalists and even the European Commission delegation.

For all these reasons, we wish to raise our voices and make an appeal: first, to political parties to condemn the acts of violence perpetrated by their supporters, and second, to the Government itself to reopen spaces for citizen participation.

a citizen, who respects freedom of expression, who ceases to prohibit marches, and who allows all NGOs to receive aid from international cooperation, not only those in Venezuela, for pro-governmental associations.
Equally, that it repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases where the mother's life is at risk.

And finally, we also want to ask the Commission that in the negotiations of the association agreement between Central America and the European Union, Nicaragua be reminded to respect the principles of the rule of law, democracy, and justice.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to our continued provision of assistance from Europe for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, whom we desire to have the best possible future.
Thank you, Madam President. I will be referring to the Breyer report.
And I must say that European farmers are fully aware that when using plant protection products, particular attention must be paid to human health and also to the protection of the environment.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact this regulation may have on the future.
It is the case that there are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that due to the limited future availability of plant protection products, it will be very difficult to
control of pests and diseases affecting the cultivation of a large quantity of food, specifically all Mediterranean products, and also the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the three-way dialogue has been the result of a arduous negotiation, and I cannot fail to recognize the work done by the drafters.

However, it must be noted that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, particularly insecticides, of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient quantity of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, keeping in mind that the danger often lies not in the product itself, but in its misuse.
For all of these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PP-Edei Group…supports the proposals requesting the evaluation of an impact…and will vote in favor of the amendments…
from Mr. Stardi, which I myself have signed, regarding endocrine disruptors and those that favor the availability of plant protection products in emergency situations.

Furthermore, if this regulation is adopted in the terms of the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and an increase in prices, leading us to import those very foods that we do not produce, alongside the products we are currently producing.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Capato, your report is a report brimming with good will. The most evident proof of this is that it merited no amendments during its consideration by the liberty committee.
Were you yourself the one who introduced 18 amendments to your own report?
And those are the amendments that have introduced a degree of radicalism—let’s say, in general terms—that raises very serious doubts for me.
I would structure the amendments you have proposed into four distinct categories. That you have proposed them to yourself, I insist, in a report that initially received the support of all groups.
Some impossibilities. You are requesting some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are requesting things for which there is no legal basis as yet. For example, until the Treaty of Lisbon enters into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Something very similar has just been told to you by Commissioner Wallström. Or you request, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no longer any time.
Therefore, you are requesting things that are impossible.
Furthermore, he requests some others that are inadvisable.
For example, you request that there be transparency in the meetings of political groups.
No man.
where privacy is needed, privacy is a political good.
If I wish to dissent from my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do so privately, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency should be demanded of public bodies, but not within political parties, where debates must be guaranteed in privacy.
Therefore, I cannot follow him/her in that.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that 90% of legislative activity is pro-environmental.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato...
Furthermore, climatology inherently incorporates standards of transparency.

If what we are going to do now is to create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be acting against what we seek to achieve, which is transparency—something that is very close to simplicity.
And finally, before the gentleman presiding calls me to order, because I am already consuming my time, there are a few things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very appealing and very attractive to public opinion to say transparency in the activity of the deputies, that it be known that they come to the plenary sessions.
That is well known, Mr. Capato.
What goes to the committees is already known. There is a record of all of them. They are accessible acts for all citizens.
Or the diets they charge for, you know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very advantageous in terms of public opinion and that it serves well to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is making things appear as they are. And when one contributes to things not appearing as they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.
I watch the situation in Gaza with horror, pain, and shame, but also with the commitment to defend peace and those who suffer the most, and to maintain dignity and hope.
Horror at the repeated scene of children murdered and women torn apart in their endless suffering following the bombings of the ghetto that Gaza has become.
The same horror that Picasso depicted in his Guernica, our Guernica devastated by the Junkers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
Shared grief with so many victims of so much suffering.
and shame for the inability of all – of our states, of the European Union, and of the international community – first to prevent and then to end the criminal aggression that we have denounced.
Shame and indignation at so much falsehood, so much ambiguity, and so much verbiage.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and do not act with the necessary and required firmness and coherence.
Therefore, history will hold many accountable as accomplices to the crime, if not for direct participation.
Because it is better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door open to hope, the European Union must support the Security Council's belated resolution.
to ensure strict compliance, just as our association agreement with Israel, which stipulates its suspension in the face of conduct such as that which is occurring, must be strictly adhered to.
Incidentally, it is never also responsible for the media blackout that I have yet to hear anyone denounce.

We must say to Israel, with clear and unambiguous firmness, that it must cease killing, allow the wounded to heal, and provide sustenance to the affected populations, and that its conduct against international law must, it absolutely must, have consequences in its relations with Europe.
I wish to greet the few European volunteer young people who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, in particular Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of this Europe of ours, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, as we can see, the textile sector has been experiencing a significant crisis in recent times, leading to numerous company closures, relocations, and unemployment—events that are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

Given this current economic situation of crisis, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sector with social measures, with plans for companies undergoing restructuring and currently facing serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and reskilling of the textile sector.
particularly to small and medium-sized enterprises that predominantly comprise the sector in the European Union and which suffer to a greater extent from the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to reinstate the system of control over imports originating from abroad and, particularly, from China due to their volume.
It is not about promoting trade barriers at all,

This concerns mitigating the negative effects of such a significant transformation. It is also important to remember that the European Union is the world's second-largest exporter of textile products and plant-based garments.

which makes it necessary to guarantee the best possible access conditions to third-country markets essential for the future of the textile and garment industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.
All of this, of course, ensuring fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this regard, the publication of accurate information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the "Made In" indication, which, as far as we know, has not been implemented, would be of great utility, since
Among other things, it would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr. Romeva, the Spanish Government need not worry; it will cooperate as it always has.

I would like to remind you that in this matter, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Investigative Commission and the one who answered all the questions, including their own.

From this Chamber, we have long been denouncing the torture and inhuman and degrading treatment being committed at the military base in Guantánamo in the name of the fight against international terrorism.
Therefore, we applaud Obama’s decision to suspend trials for four months and his objective of permanently closing the prison within a year.
However, although the responsibility rests with the United States Government, the Union cannot turn a blind eye and must offer its collaboration to achieve the closure of the detention center.
We must also consider the possibility of accepting prisoners originating from countries where human rights are not guaranteed, should the United States not request it.

Then we will have to provide a common European response, in which the Spanish Government will participate, within the framework of international law, and through a case-by-case analysis of the legal situation of each citizen, each detainee, their origin and detention, and their circumstances.

Mr. President, within the EU there are various cases of languages native to historical European peoples that, due to not being constituted as states, are not permitted to be used in the debates of this Parliament. And this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One such case is that of the Basque language, euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish State.

But the same does not occur, and please do not take this personally, Commissioner, regarding the Basque Country, affiliated with the French State, whose president, before the UN Assembly, asserts that denying respect to national identities and languages fuels humiliation, and that without that respect, there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, or Occitan receive the slightest official consideration nor do they have support to respect or encourage their use.

Therefore, I request that the Agency for Fundamental Rights examine and work to ensure that within the Member States, the rights of no European people's mother tongue are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all are considered official within their respective territories.

Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I want to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his excellent work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our Chamber.
With this directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The objective of this directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.

We want the unjust, meager wages paid to immigrants to disappear, and furthermore, we want them to cease depressing average wages, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require considerable courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and a great deal of money circulating in the shadow economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently with generosity but with responsibility.
It would be easy to succumb to the temptation of not attempting to curtail the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave approximately eight million undocumented immigrants in a state of defenselessness, facing working conditions akin to slavery.
Honorable members, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic, and even criminal, sanctions in the most serious cases are necessary to deter business owners.
We will thus reduce the pool of undeclared economic activity and curtail the incentive for migration that arises from the possibility of irregular employment.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

Therefore, we want to continue with the global approach and ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr. Baró, to present the new Blue Cards, "Blue Cards," for the other occupational categories as soon as possible.
Dear colleagues, Mrs. Ferrero Balner, Mr. Solana, I would first like to thank the three speakers for their work, and as rapporteur in the shadows of the report on CFSP, I will refer to

Regarding this report in particular, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Sarisbolski on the outcome of his work and for the collaboration he has fostered among the other groups to achieve a consensus-based result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, so too does this Chamber know how to demonstrate cohesion in relation to the evaluation and promotion of major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

Our group, the Socialist Group, has focused on a dual direction. On one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key for us, transversally across all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

peace throughout the planet or a wager on human development. On the other hand, proposing elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CFSP with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared, or introducing them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and increased relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only remember when particularly virulent wars occur, and sometimes not even then.

Regarding Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current processes of negotiation for association agreements, the first of a bioregional nature that the European Union will conclude throughout its history.

Regarding the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that speaks only of security, to instead include the rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona process.

Regarding amendments for the Plenary, our group has not submitted any, believing that this would somehow reinforce the balance achieved through concessions and, therefore, we will oppose the majority of the amendments so as not to weaken the agreement reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee. Thank you.
Thank you, President. Venezuela’s referendum has concluded with a victory for the “yes” vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that equality of opportunity has not existed in the campaign and that the ruling party has enjoyed the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagements, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.

In that sense, we criticize the decision by the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament and, even more so, the manner in which that expulsion was carried out. But we appeal to this Parliament to avoid...

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local legislation, and even less so that they insult a head of state, however critical that head of state may be.
With these attitudes, we are jeopardizing future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council presenting an overall positive assessment of the process regarding its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he noted that «they were seeking to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, they were leveling serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and they were bordering on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation».
Our Parliament should not instigate any type of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
Conversely, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member of parliament to provide explanations to this Chamber regarding actions that affect us all.
The Budget Committee opines that the clear delimitation of each budgetary instrument is of the utmost importance.

From a budgetary perspective, the funding proposal from the Development Commission appears unsuitable, as that money does not exist, even.
to account for those lines with an amount of credit assigned on a multi-year basis. There is credit for 2009, but not beyond that.
In any case, given that the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is advisable to reverse it.
remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the various budget headings.
Well, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission likely has other matters of greater concern than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a report from the Commission, a report on the implementation of regulation 1206-2001 concerning…
Council Decision of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the judicial authorities of Member States in the obtaining of evidence in civil or commercial matters.

We are in an area that is truly not communal, but rather intergovernmental, in which, through the Council and its regulations, efforts have been made to stimulate cooperation among those judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

...that is to say, certain measures have been foreseen......for example, the issuing of practical guides......the utilization of electronic media......etcetera, but I acknowledge that it is quite difficult......an action by the Commission...

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to achieve it given the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.

That is to say, we are requesting that judicial authorities who collaborate with one another—we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities managing 22 different languages—achieve results, despite having very distinct legal systems.
The Commission has observed that the results are not positive, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and certainly that we do not have the means to do so.
Ideally, one would have access to material resources,
For example, what could the Commission do to equip judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements, such as a video conferencing system?
The video conference may be a utopia for many small courts throughout the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We would need to reinforce this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, anything related to the training of judges is fundamental.
This is something the Commission cannot do on its own, either.
but the Commission can indeed stimulate the development of this type of training courses in Community law and in knowledge of the various legal systems.
Then there is a significant difficulty, which is the problem of languages—that is, how can one communicate, let us say, a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge with such different languages.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to manage their own law, which is already complex in itself, are obligated to possess knowledge for these kinds of matters.
What practical steps can we take to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
What could we do to help them achieve it?
When presenting this report, demonstrate no rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I believe the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of having a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, what does the commission believe can be done to provide a greater response?
rigor to this 2001 regulation, somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntaristic, and I'm not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or if it can be used to achieve progress.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we experienced a significant maritime accident, that of the Erika ship, near the French coast, which gave rise to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at addressing and preventing accidents.

We believed we had already banished the danger, but shortly thereafter the coasts of Galicia were devastated by the sludge from another accident even greater than the first, that of the private vessel.

Since then, within the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the excessive resistance encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, as a result of cuts prompted by the Council, they proved ineffective in their initial drafting.

We approved the regulations for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for Major Oil Catastrophes, and safe havens. And now we review and approve the liability of passenger shipping companies, the investigation of matters.

maritime accidents, the Community system for the monitoring and information exchange of maritime traffic, control by the port State authority, and finally the regulations and directive concerning ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to come into effect and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible time.
Therefore, I feel satisfied.
But the legislature ends, I leave Parliament, and I depart with the regret of not having managed to establish as mandatory the introduction of control systems that exist and exist.
They are patented to determine when and how much sludge and fuel tank waste has been illegally discharged into the sea by a specific vessel.
That is to say, a type of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities whenever a ship arrives in port.

I believe that we owe the marine environment greater attention and stricter procedures to address the extensive pollution we generate, and if we fail to do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another 10 years to control illegal marine discharges more effectively and efficiently.
Mr. President, the revision of the Noviñeta Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially peripheral countries, who feel they are victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internationalization of the external costs of road transport by assigning three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal—that those who use pay, and those who pollute pay—are reasonable, the solution proposed is not, in any way, and will be discriminatory toward a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it wasn’t the objective, has proven to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transportation, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

individuals in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their end consumer. A consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these tariffs.

Esteemed colleagues, we need a transportation system that is competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly, without overlooking the road, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, and cross-border connections remain, in some cases, projects rather than reality.
Distinguished members, when the behemoth of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, let alone for merriment.

The European Commission, on 15 July 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European External Action Service, on 13 October, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, awaiting the Parliament’s opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that already during the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee European Union-Mexico, held at the end of October of last year, we stated that a
A strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We noted the opportune moment for relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current comprehensive agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, particularly in the face of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, a commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and the respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations regarding the Strategic Association European Union of Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
Regarding the report on microcredit, I would like to congratulate all the speakers because they have done a great job.
undoubtedly improved the commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to lay the foundation for developing a genuine framework within the European Union for the microcredit sector.
that has been successful in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as an instrument for improving social inclusion and job creation.

but that had not transitioned to the sector or the community context. And I believe that this is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
prioritized in that regard, strengthening the initiatives advanced here, but further steps must be taken.
It is necessary to increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure.
It is necessary to facilitate access for individuals and companies that do not have access to loans, and in that sense, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of...
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate that access and be included in the report.
And I conclude that this will undoubtedly lay the groundwork for us to create a harmonious framework within the European context that promotes the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of aid for coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
I say this with due advance because, inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed themselves to express a contrary view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
It will be necessary to continue supporting my country’s coal after 2012, and I want that noted in the minutes of the session.
Gentlemen, officials, limit yourselves to complying with the current plan and, subsequently, beginning in 2012, with the instrument that we will begin negotiating with the sector next year.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bocland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Bloch, not only for the question, but also for the solution he has prepared.

Within the People's Party, we support the fight against improper practices and methods used to reduce ship sizes and, therefore, we support Mr. Brokland’s proposed resolution. However, there are certain points that concern us.

The first is section 3, which he has also indicated, stating that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have submitted an amendment to this section because there are differing interpretations both within and outside the European Union, and we believe the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradict it, but the future international agreement on ship recycling should define the details of its application.
The draft resolution also requests, in point 14, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us rather premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time, when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what system will be adopted for this financing. And it seems to me that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter either.
Finally, in point 15, the commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
We believe it is the Commission’s prerogative to decide this, which must also be determined in an international agreement.

The key is to ensure coherence regarding the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, and all of this taking into account not only the Basel Convention, but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and to congratulate us all because, during times of economic crisis, it is fundamental to maintain a program like this with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure initiated by the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, in these moments of economic uncertainty from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned or
not only concerned with the recovery of the financial system, but fully aware that social policies, especially those supporting those most in need, the poorest within the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here we concur with the commission. Furthermore, because European agriculture has a distinct social character, because it is an effective instrument, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, as is the case with the rapporteur, we oppose the co-financing of this programme between the European Union and the Member States, as this would entail discrimination between States according to their wealth, potentially leading to the situation whereby the programme cannot be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is incomprehensible that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wishes to economize on Community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
43 million potential beneficiaries of this program are demanding greater effort and, in no case, a reduction in budgetary expenditure.
Austerity, yes, but not for the most vulnerable.
It is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of distributed foodstuffs.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses arising from the distribution, including those of transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food should preferably be community-sourced and of quality.
It is a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the plan for distributing fruit in schools.
That’s all, and many thanks.
We hope that the Commission will consider the position of this Parliament when the vote takes place and, above all, that the plan is implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions of our planet.
The consequences of an unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, thus making a new global regulation necessary to protect the Arctic, similar to the one that already exists for Antarctica, even taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty among all parties involved—including, undoubtedly, the European Union—is necessary to protect its unique environment, to ensure the fully sustainable nature of all types of human activities, and to multilaterally regulate navigation along the new sea routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation for managing common problems.

At these moments of difficulties and uncertainty, we must elevate that spirit and that harmony to greater heights to prevent states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical conflicts, forgetting what should be the common objective: the preservation of a vast shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of those who have spoken.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it is said that we need to seek a more intelligent model for conducting business, what is actually being discussed is abolishing intellectual property.
business can only be conducted if there is an established right.

achieved within the remit of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms. McGill and Mr. Tubongo.
I believe it is a magnificent directive, a directive that will enhance the creation of intellectual property.
And furthermore, that directive includes several recommendations with respect to the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval by this Chamber of that report, and I hope that the Council aligns with the lines of the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, will serve to ensure that in the next legislature the

The committee should continue along this path, make proposals to the Parliament, and advance in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Yes, Mr. President, the information you are giving me is correct, but the impression we, the European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens, have is that there is a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this moment, as fiscal demands are strengthened in each of the Member States, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission the reason for the pragmatic approach, it is because the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a kind of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers matters to the Council and the Council refers them back to the Commission. But in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build do not have the opportunity to live in different countries or establish relationships as a consequence of the heavy tax burden that a lack of fiscal harmonization can entail.
fiscal. Can the Council do anything to help us break this vicious cycle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the usual speaker is not present, that Mr. Tajani has come, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
As a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we Members of the European Parliament feel regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to criticize the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and the application of Community law are based on indirect implementation.

That is to say, the Commission has only a few officials at headquarters where it receives some complaints and has some avenues for action. But at this moment, there is also a trend toward limiting budgetary powers, which means the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the implementation of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, in this regard, I don’t believe we can expect too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission. And I believe that in Mrs. Frazzoni’s report there are some points that could be useful in achieving this application.
I refer to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the actions of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my colleague, my group member here present, Marían, I had the opportunity to visit.
and of being present in this tribunal and of being aware of the immense work that this tribunal was undertaking, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been stated here, has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution clearly indicates, it is the first international court financed by voluntary contributions, the first tribunal established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and also the first court, as has already been noted, to try a former prime minister.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but because it serves as a reference for other tribunals that have been created at its instance, such as Rwanda, former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, on which we have been working jointly with the tribunal for several months.
Two years ago, we approved a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the tribunal was experiencing a difficult period in which it was running out of rulings.
...and it lacked sufficient support. We must acknowledge here the European Commission as well...for coming out in support, let's say, financially, of this court.

We are primarily requesting two things now. First, that convicted individuals serve their sentences. Not only the functioning of the tribunal, which concludes next year, is at stake, but also the legacy this tribunal will leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by greater funding.
Ultimately, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have prosecuted war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which upon entering the courtroom we observed a motto written that read “Without justice, there is no peace.”
And precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this tribunal remains permanent in history.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. With all due brevity, which I trust my Lords and Ladies will appreciate by this hour. Mr. Vice Chairman of the Committee, many thanks once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did with the third package, more...

that its impetus, its political standing, has been capable of driving an agreement near the Council and making it possible for Parliament, the Council, and the Commission to reach agreement at this juncture and in these subsequent days as the legislature concludes.
