I have been missing a minute. Before that, I want to respond to the lady commissioner, who is aware of my friendship and affection for her, and indeed of my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the police commissioner has not said a single word about the Public Defender's recommendation.

That is to say, the rapporteur of the people, who knows all the arguments given to us by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission appears to be ignoring in all its aspects.

I don't even want Mrs. Cuneva to reply to me because it's evident that she is not the one who has the data. But all the data she has given me is consistent with what we knew and with what the ombudsman also knows. And she doesn't tell us whether...

Despite all of that, and as the ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends changing the regulation, he does not tell us whether the Commission will assume what the ombudsman requests and what the Parliament recommends based on the ombudsman’s request.
Mr. President, I believe that the regulatory proposals submitted to us by the committee are important and necessary. Furthermore, it was also important and necessary that from the
The European Parliament insisted on the principles on which both European Parliament rapporteurs, Mr. Zivieska and Mr. Depré, have insisted—namely, the principle of community competition.

This concerns a matter of community competence wherein, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain Member State competencies, but as Mr. Barró has stated, limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is unavailable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament have the power to relinquish those community competencies.

Having established this, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

But I also hope that, from now on, and building on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as has been highlighted, for example, by Mr. Sogor in his latest intervention.
We are discussing the problems that most directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve those problems for people, people will realize that the European Union has a function.

Ultimately, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. Debrey and Mr. Esviesca, and to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and requested to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was called an expulsion, but which in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague, Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to confirm that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of the opposition, threats, the disregard for human dignity, and the manipulative use of justice are customary practices in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel’s back and that has led to this resolution. However, there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the resolution, and others that are not.
As is the case with Hije Ocedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and also because he voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied thanks to the assistance of others and, specifically, Citibank, and managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and furthermore, later lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas jail, illegally, after two years of having been detained without any complainant bringing charges.
Their only crime, being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is that of Niso Moreno, a student leader at the Universidad de los Andes, elected on several occasions to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 election for the Federation, against the current Minister of Interior and Justice. And this is his crime.
Today he is accused of attempted homicide, lewd acts, and violence, among other things, despite having been exonerated of all charges.

Situations like yours are commonplace in this country, where the persecution of one’s opponent, with the intent of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent, have become everyday occurrences.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy despite the difficulties. I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be defeated at the polls.

Madam President, Commissioner,
it is undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all that has been achieved, the southern part of the Union is burning, and burning more and more.
Therefore, the resolution that this Parliament is about to adopt cannot be merely a resolution that serves to highlight the great concern that we feel for the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

Regardless of any responsibilities that may exist in certain states or autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act with swiftness and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, within reach.
Neither the victims, nor the suffering endured, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy, nor can they comprehend budgetary shortfalls.
We must prioritize and we must act. And to act, in this case, is to modify strategies, mobilize resources, increase them, and coordinate preventative policies optimally, demanding, when the

case of responsibilities to those states lacking them. But assuming this is not a problem of states in southern Europe, and that climate change does not only affect certain states, it affects all and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the principal tasks that this Parliament, in the immediate future, must be to ensure that the European Union secures, for the Copenhagen summit, clear and

decisive measures to attenuate greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are evidently at the root of the fires, of their causes, and these in turn contribute to the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this resolution is now the challenge facing this Parliament, with all certainty.
But let that challenge of the commission be met, if indeed, Commissioner, you truly want to prevent the south of the Union—which does exist—from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I address Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have followed you with great interest and with deep respect for a long time, ever since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have me utterly astonished at present.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have demonstrated a disregard for the group in which I am present, the group of non-registered individuals, by not granting us even a minute of your time to come and tell us your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have demonstrated a disregard for all of our constituents.
Secondly, due to the fragility of their political project, and the paucity of their political proposals in the document "Political Orientations for the Next Commission."
Proposals that do not even manage to capture what you have defended throughout your own term as president of the Commission.
It has surprised me in this regard that matters such as energy, which throughout your tenure have been well addressed, are now, when you offer us your proposals for the next…

Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by telling us that you had already taken all necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, correcting is the mark of wise people.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very well applied to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been experiencing one of the most severe crises in its history for months, and despite this, due to an unwillingness to yield, either on the part of the European Commission or some governments, including, it seems, my own – the Spanish government – they refuse to reverse the decisions regarding the health check of the CAP.
Those decisions were adopted without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was fulfilled.
It gives the impression that the Member States either did not want to or were unable to see the storm brewing at the time.
The reform became obsolete in a short time due to the significant shift the market has taken, a shift that demonstrates the sector’s complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved the largest absolute increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the very ones requesting a review of the monitoring decisions, is quite thought-provoking.

In my view, the Member States erred and should have listened more attentively to voices, among which I include myself, that requested postponing any final decision regarding the sector's future until 2011.
It is a pity that they did not listen to us.
Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the palace of chimera, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us encouragement and strength to continue prospering and building a strong Europe, and above all, a federal Europe.
Only thus would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the founders of Europe, through whose efforts we all are here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concern generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is, in my opinion, time to consider the treatment that should be given in the future to the nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction.
My contention is that these impediments cannot come free of charge.
With a clear head, it is time to consider the possible measures to adopt in the coming days and years.
This modest deputy desires a future President of the Council who is a man, or better, a woman, convinced of European federalism, and capable of managing the
who is located in the Schengen Area and who is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
That is to say, on behalf of the commission I would have nothing further to add, amen, but I had already prepared an intervention in the name of the Socialist group.

The breakdown of constitutional order in Honduras breaks two decades without coups in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, particularly the more vulnerable ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and mute in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting the mediation of President Arias in line with the position unanimously adopted by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Micheletti, has failed to uphold the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and obstructing the return, among other measures, of the incumbent president, Mr. Zelaya, to the presidency.

Under current circumstances, the election of a new president in the scheduled November 29th polls suffers from an inherent lack of legitimacy, and their results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is characterized by being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Vaclav Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, consequently, proponents of freedom. And therefore, let us speak of Cuba, of China, of North Korea, or now of Honduras—our discourse must be resolute in defense of freedom.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only liberty-killers and repressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and with that, a very dangerous precedent will have been created, and the doctrine of the "good," temporary, and not particularly insightful coup will have triumphed.

I wish to congratulate the members of the Environment Committee, and its president, Mr. Leine, for the work they have done so that we may have a resolution like the one we have before us, and which we must approve decisively.
We can settle for simply stating that we have sufficient coverage with sector-specific agreements, because discussing a patchwork agreement is already acknowledging a portion of the failure.
We must proceed to approve this resolution, which encompasses three noble aspirations.
A more evident one is the avoidance of climate change, with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and a commitment to funding, aspiring to a binding agreement—I say, not a patchwork.

And two latent aspirations. One is to begin sooner rather than later to work toward having a common energy policy, as we once established a common agricultural policy because it was necessary. And the other, of course, which is also included, is to regain citizens’ trust in politics and in politicians—something we are not overflowing with in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting president of the Council to continue with his optimism, to exert pressure and negotiate everything possible to bring others along to this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be discredited before history for being unable to reach a binding agreement. But I, as a parliamentarian, and I believe all representatives of the people, cannot be discredited before history for having failed in Copenhagen to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity to avert climate change.

Today, there is no doubt regarding the European Union’s commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to advance in this space of freedom, justice, and security that is so vital.

But in my understanding, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among the Member States. However, the time has come, and with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislation in the direction of the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this occurs, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, happens, and could continue to happen, with the consequent harm to victims of terrorism, who see those who murdered their loved ones treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore request that this Parliament promote or adopt the European Charter on the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of human memory.
Thank you, President. I would first like to congratulate Ms. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role of the CAP in addressing food supply needs on an international scale.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget—a point that must be stated very clearly, the CAP is no longer a priority—but food sufficiency certainly should be. And in past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Therefore, agriculture cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy capable of thriving in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move his business forward, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and high-quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
Therefore, I believe that a change of direction in the CAP would need to occur, but not its disappearance.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to re-establishing a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater stability in prices, which would have a positive impact not only on farmers but also on consumers and third-country nations.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of best practices to foster balanced relationships among the various actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a more equitable distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food security, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries where significantly lower standards are applied to those imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own domestic markets for a genuine matter of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, approximately 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union in 2009.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union be primarily based on the protection of victims, with particular attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand idly by as witnesses to this spectacle, this display of sexual exploitation unfolding before our very eyes.
Therefore, I fully support this Parliament’s request that assistance to victims be unconditional, more robust, and involve more severe penalties, as Mr. Barrot just stated.
Having said this, I would like to request the President and the Council to utilize all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European Protection Order for Victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates of the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to fruition, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

I also expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency to ensure that this order offers victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems facing our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely serious problem of human trafficking, and that we will not be left with mere words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard like myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as president of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges inherent in this period, and we certainly cannot fail to meet the expectations that have been created.
May citizenship perceive that our renewed institutions are instruments capable of providing solutions to real problems.
The program presented by your Lordship is known to be shared by us.
that for the Popular Party of Spain this is a matter of state and that we will be supporting their Lordship in everything that we see to be common interests of Europe and that is important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and one that I hope will be filled with content.
I would like for people to see, given that it will certainly be colorful and varied, in each event a milestone concerning real problems that affect them.
The crisis is hitting economies, and unemployment appears as a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that 20% of unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
...what I believe is that it obligates us all to produce... a solution or a problem, really, that we must solve together...
That is a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain faces many challenges ahead. I believe, I am certain of Spain’s capabilities as a nation. And I want to believe, and I am certain, that you will rise to the level of our country.

We cannot fail to meet these expectations at this hour for Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world—a point which has been intelligently noted—results in the emergence of new power centers, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should question our capacity to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.
We must also have the humility to accept those pieces of advice from Don Quixote that Sancho gave him when he recommended humility in the dreaming of governing the Barataria island.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has continued to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Indeed, the formation of a truly equitable government and the courageous manner in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action program, certainly against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender-Based Violence is a pioneering proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
The women with Zapatero.
Mr. President, thank you. On a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And unfortunately, we are advancing through a series of attacks, such as the failed Detroit attack, which obliges us today to make decisions that guarantee the security of air transport.
Addressing concerns regarding body scanners in airports is a responsibility that we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot continue waiting because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the commission must as soon as possible guarantee to us that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Granted this, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say that there is no right higher than the right to live. And those of us who love freedom above all else, we need to live securely in order to feel truly free.
Mr. President, I believe this crisis is an opportunity to advance firmly and with conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that robust Europe, it is likely that the expression "improve coordination" should be discarded, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and, strictly speaking, refers to paralysis and to indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debt of European countries will suffer until progress is made toward European financial integration and eurobonds are not issued.

In any case, European institutions can already undertake concrete actions. I will not reiterate the rhetoric of coordination. And there they are, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision, and on the other hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wanted to state that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the law recently enacted in Spain regarding abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am particularly concerned about defending the women whose lives are endangered by gender-based violence, and to offer them a space in which they can live free and safe.

This Parliament’s resolution of 2 February 2006 recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established a space of freedom, justice, and security for all European citizens and considered the fight against gender-based violence a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency that it promote during its term a European Order for the Protection of Victims of Gender-Based Violence, to ensure that victims of these crimes receive the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender-based violence should also have no borders, and Member States should strive to harmonize their legislation so that the fight against abuse towards women transcends

legislative obstacles, and ultimately, we could, at least within the European Union, protect the lives of women and their children, and we could—I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to do everything

necessary and everything within his power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a highly effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect the dignity of women or their right to live free and safe.

It is now a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, ideals that resonated so profoundly and inspired so much hope for the peoples of the world, for the brightest of international youth.
What characterizes, however, the Castro brothers’ dictatorship at this moment is the irreverence towards political and conscientious prisoners, the irreverence against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco, with the mistreatment of political prisoners he also considered common. His own obsessive disdain for the exiled.
Castro ends up like Franco and all enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be supportive of those who struggle and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Thank you, President. President of the Council, Commissioner, never again, never again let our silence become complicity with those who curtail freedoms.

Never again shall we allow a person who was fighting for their rights and the rights of all to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our voice rising, strong and firm, demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old man of color, a bricklayer who was simply requesting improved prison conditions, died after 86 days of a hunger strike and 7 years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
and during those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and ill-treated by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, a dense silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, including psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Your Honor, the resolution we present today, that we debate today, and that we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
They pronounce once more in favor of a democratic transition and the strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not delve into a divisive topic at this time regarding whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us now focus on the topic of saving lives and human rights.
And we spoke of a period of serene reflection in which we seek meeting points on the themes of Cuba’s future politics.
But this text also possesses a significant added value.
The fact that it is being presented by six political groups expresses a new era of broad scope within this Chamber on the matter of human rights.

Let it never again be asserted that European democratic conservatives bend to the, quoted, dictates of American imperialism. But let it also never again be said that social democrats are acquiescent or are accomplices of the communist dictatorship.
Simply because both assertions are false, and the victims of those who champion tyranny wherever they may be must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, I would like to conclude by thanking Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People’s Party, Ms. Weber from the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr. Rodríguez.

On behalf of the Green Group, to Mr. Karsutnik, of the European Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope tomorrow successful endeavor.

Finally, I would also like to thank the Prime Minister of Spain and President of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in bringing forward this resolution that we are debating today.
History will absolve me was the famous plea of a young lawyer who stirred his people.
History absolves him of the effects of his rebellion against tyranny and subsequently against the North American blockade.
But with the same emphatic condemnation, this Parliament, representing the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that
The people of Cuba suffer, the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, the disdain for its exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this resolution, members of parliament from all ideologies, we stand alongside Cubans who are fighting.
One must avoid at all possible means the brutal repression they suffer, even surpassing the paralyzing call of common position.
Tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the final verse of his Habana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are secure.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week marked the celebration of International Women's Day.
In this Parliament, we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that, yes, violence against women can be eradicated.

Today we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems appropriate to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the military or the police, and even homicide.
Regrettably, to date, the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and thus it is correctly spoken of near absolute impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides, a harsh but accurate term, when we see that almost the entirety of murders committed against women remain in impunity.
For example, in the State of Mexico, over the past four years, only 11% of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two Indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to 21 years in prison and up to
Now, more than three years have passed in prison, for kidnapping the women during an incident in a market—six men from the Federal Investigation Agency.
Investigation. Hopefully, the judge—who will decide in a week on the appeal in this case—will recognize the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women begins in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence are defined and the mechanisms are established to make the regulations operational.
Similarly, it would be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this topic becomes a primary concern of young people’s education.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr. Escotá for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a genuine pleasure working with him and with the other spokespersons for the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position like this one that defends quality, that champions development, and that emphasizes the value of rural areas, not solely as environment.

not merely testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as genuine generators of wealth and employment. Employment that we so greatly need now during these times of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.
We also appreciate the defense maintained by this European Parliament and the position already held, which it has made clear, by the Agriculture Committee: to champion quality to the highest degree.
And at that maximum level, we are certainly committed to maintaining that differentiation between protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Certainly, we reject the ideas of lowering the standard of quality and want attention to be given and value placed on community production.
I applaud the words of Commissioner Cholo.
It was certainly pleasant to hear him, to hear him speak of the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
We certainly hope you hear that voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

Finally, I would like to say that we hope it never happens again that the European Commission preempts this Parliament by prohibiting things like, for example, marketing standards for fruits and vegetables, which have done so much damage to European free competition.
We want market imbalances to correct themselves, and we also want to invest in quality, variety, food safety, and an appropriate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food productions to be defended within the World Trade Organization.
And for that, we also count, of course, on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because neither our producers nor our European consumers can remain defenseless.
Thank you, President. The Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us then be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many agreements to introduce community competition over European airspace.
But if we were unable to intervene as we should have in the sky, we could certainly do so on the skin of the earth.
for example, monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transportation,
No minimum services. Maximum services to all parties.
Thank you very much, President.
The procedure, electoral systems, and the election of deputies to the European Parliament present problems. That means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

that was a mandate already enshrined in the Treaties of Rome. And for this reason, the coordinators—and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Messrs. Jauregui and Duff—have agreed to a suitable amendment.

Tomorrow, a vote will be held, and I hope that this Chamber will support it precisely so that this matter, this question of a uniform electoral procedure advised to the European Parliament, can be resolved shortly.
I believe that would eliminate this type of query.

In his intervention, Mr. Traskowski has spoken of the necessary representativeness of this Chamber. And this is a factor that the majority of speakers, including the Vice-President Sefcovich, have highlighted.
I concur, and as we state in Article 1 of the report, that the 18 should enter as a block, because otherwise, we would lose representativeness.

And so that they may act as a bloc, to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, sir, be pragmatic because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional measures or solutions.

And that is why, I don't hide it, I don't like the possibility of deputies entering this Chamber who did not emerge from the 2009 elections. I say this with complete clarity in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and them not entering…

either enter into force at 18 or seek a pragmatic solution that enters into force at 18 and, therefore, fulfill the Lisbon Agreement. I ask this Chamber – and this is the basis of my report – to opt for that transitional, pragmatic, but above all, Madam President, just solution.
Thank you all for the collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do on March 11th, International Day of Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay tribute to them today from this Parliament, a tribute that recognizes the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin working on a directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the forgotten ones, and who endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their perpetrators.
It is now time for these European institutions to recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and to assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article be that support for victims of terrorism is recognized as having the right to justice and that no government ever pays a political price.

I issue a call to all those who can defend victims to never forget that true peace is born of justice, and it is the only peace we, who believe in justice, must defend from Europe and from any place in the world.

It has been necessary, Mr. President, to find ourselves on the brink of the abyss and economic collapse for the Heads of State and Government to understand that the path forward is not one of greater nationalism, but one of greater Europe.
At this juncture, measures have been implemented, such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the nascent form of a European public asset.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have become aware that we are all navigating the same vessel and that addressing individual situations, particularly in an ad hoc manner, is futile.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, conversely, the beginning of a genuine European economic governance. Because what we lack, dear colleagues, is authentic governance, and what is in surplus is stewardship, if we are to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, incidentally, nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only sound recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Thank you, President. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, thank you to Ms. Desarnet for the collaboration we have had.
Now more than ever, unity around the Mediterranean is necessary, as is the strengthening of major projects and institutional development.
Now more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

To that end, it is necessary to promote and finalize commercial and economic relationships in the region, with measures both in the short and long term. Free trade zone, suppression of tariff barriers, and opening of north-south and south-south markets.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the possibility of a new commitment, a new situation, a new exchange of views, and the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit could position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Thank you, President. Within the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, it is vital because this axis is a priority, given that it would connect Algeciras with Europe...
Without excluding other priority corridors, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.
And why? So stated the Reding precinct. It cited greater economic activity and significant concentration of ground transportation.
This is one of the two conditions.
…the possibility arose of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean area…
Economic momentum must be gained, and competitiveness fostered, as the Commissioner also stated, because in this region more than 50% of Spanish exports originate.
Therefore, if we expand the theme of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Thank you, President. I wanted to take this minute to congratulate the rotating Spanish presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the
a common position with regard to Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that naturally includes, as a priority matter, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, largely due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which initiated this presidency just in January of this year.

This year, with the expulsion of the Member of Parliament speaking to you, when he was attempting to visit the island, with all the necessary visas and in full legal compliance, to express concern over human rights there.
But that policy, that new policy undertaken by the Spanish government, will yield results sooner rather than later.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is not at all easy to achieve balanced labeling that contains everything essential, but is not so exhaustive as to complicate the information.
This is an excellent report, and the opponent deserves congratulations for it.
I concur with her on the major topics relating to nutritional information and the controversial matter of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not comply with the
commitment to establish said profiles, as well as their terms of use, before January 19, 2009, as stipulated by regulation 19-24-2006.

There is a matter that concerns me, and it is the possibility of the coexistence of national regulations for labeling, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the absence of such indication, it could mislead the consumer.
Furthermore, it is anticipated that there will always be voluntary labeling...
Going further can entail economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any significant, clear benefit to the consumer.

And regarding the use of different languages......I have to say that the commission's proposal......coincides with the existing directive......which has worked well, which has not presented problems...
And reopening this debate may prove both dangerous and necessary, and could create difficulties for the producer’s distribution.
Mr. President. The best demonstration of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the committee to the full chamber.

But in addition to good intentions, I believe we must be practical when labeling food if we don't want to achieve the opposite of what we aim for. That is, confusing the consumer instead of helping them to become informed.
It is not a matter of illustrating, but of preventing, of informing them about what they can eat and to what extent.
measure. It is necessary to label regarding fats, regarding sugars, regarding trans fats,
Indeed.
...that effectively concerns the matter of cholesterol......all those substances that affect what we have said......obesity and people's health...

Yes, but other foods with additional information, such as place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or for example, in meat—that is, the place of birth, place of passage, grazing location, and the place of slaughter—can illustrate a great deal, but they will ultimately cause confusion.

It is up to us to ensure that we are practical and that this regulation becomes the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, conversely, the one that will confuse them further and impose issues that, instead of achieving better health outcomes, will result in greater degrees of confusion.

Therefore, I request, for example, that some of us opt for the GDA, the guideline daily amount, instead of traffic light systems. Because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will gain weight. Therefore, consume only one.
The amount of daily intake versus other types of codes is what some propose, to avoid further confusing the consumer.

It is important to foster the development of aquaculture.

It is important to have health guarantees, it is important to have sustainability, and it is important to have protection of the marine environment.
It is necessary to strengthen the image of aquaculture, and it is also necessary to strengthen the scientific and research sector.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fragueiro has said, within the PCP, as the Commissioner was saying.

It is necessary to provide it with a coherent framework for coordination, to give it the possibility of regularization, because aquaculture can represent sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe that it is important for Europe.

Thank you, Mr. President. In my view, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new transport white paper, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report features several key milestones worthy of note. The necessity of a financial fund as an indispensable instrument. The challenge of the increasing demand for freight transport. The search for cost-effective solutions that
provide security for users and for goods. The imperative need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport. My considered and accurate diagnosis that a mere competition between the various

modes, but rather to complement each other by seeking efficiency criteria. The speaker's assertion, which I consider brave and just, that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally respectful than road transport.
Ultimately, the concept of an efficient community is a future-oriented concept and, in my judgment, should undoubtedly be supported with all rigor.
Yours, Mr. President, a fundamental error in approach.
Did you truly believe you would preside over Europe and influence the mechanisms that drive the complex European machinery?
He even came to believe, because he allowed those close to you to proclaim it, that the world was to live under his presidency a stellar moment.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let's move on to some clarifications.

Over these past six months of the Spanish presidency, I would like to distinguish between, on the one hand, its political direction and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been working behind the scenes.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the presidency of the government, which has rather swung like a pendulum.
However, I wish to highlight the efforts of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is that, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is something to regret, it is that they are unduly hampered in their daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been implemented in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to cite the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to the rights of patients in cross-border healthcare.
More questions remain in the air regarding the agreements on the new 2020 strategy and, above all, those concerning the European External Action Service, both still too fragile.
Regrettable has been the situation regarding the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender-Based Violence, and the same somber outcome has been offered by the
Basic Community Patent, vital for the life of thousands of companies, and partially blocked by the linguistic problems stimulated by Spanish legislation.

But it is all major political actions that have ended in spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to the summit of the European Union with the United States, the latter is cited in regard to which its own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must concede that the inability to advance its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the advancements made toward improved European economic governance cannot in any way be imported into your presidency, conspicuously absent in the most relevant matters.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish presidency.

A positive conclusion if I want to draw from this experience. My fantasy of being a staunch Europeanist is excited at the thought that it could signify the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived until now.

This would be welcome news, for as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, firmly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being submerged in the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, that I would have liked to deliver a different speech today.
His Lordship presented a semester brimming with ambition, setting a standard for his aspirations so high that, when compared to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that his Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation requiring leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has recalled on occasion that the European Union is a club with rules, and I concur.
But it was his Lordship who was entitled to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom their obligations were imperatively demanded.
In this instance, positive achievements have been overshadowed.
Your Honor has had time to relate them; I have not.
Democracy, Your Honor, that is a regime of public opinion.

And that is what it appears to be. Obama’s disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean summit, and the announced European Union-United States initiative constitute failures of considerable significance.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any price has not favored the image of Spanish management. The way in which some respectable objectives were achieved has been described as makeshift.
Spain is a great nation and will remain so despite poor management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained their composure, and as a result, the prestige of Spain will endure.
The truth is that the judgment passed on this presidency will weigh more heavily on Spain’s situation than on anything I have or have not done here.
It was difficult to lead such a challenging company, one that has placed its country in a period of uncertainty and unease.
It is the best-case scenario. This presidency has proven, regrettably, irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will be fully entering into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian presidency achieves what the Spanish presidency did not, namely, to channel the discussions so that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy even in the future.

A truly robust common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to address the needs of all 27 Member States, both new and established. And let it not happen as it did in 2005, when funds were lacking and modulation had to be fabricated.

In the upcoming reform of the CAP, we are staking the viability of a sector that not only contributes intangible goods and services, such as environmental stewardship, but should also ensure the provision of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, therefore it is necessary that the European Parliament provides security and supply based on community production, as the main objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, I concur with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and arrives at a timely moment, as the abuses committed by large-scale distribution have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the various links in the food chain.

The Bové Report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must nevertheless be recognized from a social market economy perspective—the very one we advocate within the European People’s Party—as it provides answers to the legitimate demands of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food supply chain, which is always beneficial, and provides greater possibilities and support for defending the more vulnerable sectors of that chain, and certainly supports European consumers so that they can learn more about it.

The European food industry could perhaps have been given more consideration within this report, and that would have been very beneficial. However, this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, which were very necessary.

Measures are also included to ensure fairness for those links in the chain, as requested by the Environment Committee. And there is also a call to combat abusive and unfair practices by large-scale distribution.
It is now time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to prohibit them definitively.
It is also important to include measures to prevent abusive practices through private label products that contravene competition and that infringe upon intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, support for the BOVE report is essential, and support must be given to all colleagues from the various parliamentary committees—INCO, ENVI, and Agriculture—who have demonstrated diligent work to ensure this report is finally published and helps European producers thrive.
The alarm bell sounds, and it is true.
And the frustration is also audible, as we are hearing in the interventions of this Plenary Session, due to the failure to achieve the Millennium Development Goals.
And the truth is, what we stand to lose is considerable.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the larger fish decided to stop eating the smaller ones, we would all have to pay for it from the generational pocket—with our health and well-being as currency.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time through pioneering and conservation measures.

But as demonstrated by the unmet objectives, it appears that there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also for expansion, to go beyond our exceedingly limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked away in a segregated area, as it sometimes appears to be, with occasional cursory glances.
Biodiversity thrives and knows no boundaries. It traverses the entire Earth with a domino effect, where if one piece falls, they all fall.

I draw attention to the need for a global and more communal will, particularly with regard to land, because subsidiarity as the sole method for managing land or forests could be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

Therefore, I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the potential vote that will be cast, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on land would help in the conservation of the entire territory.

So varied, so diverse, for good and for ill, and so lacking in political will by the States, and so in need of ever greater European union, with all the implications of the word, more union also for the soil.

Thank you, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner. First and foremost, I want to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Macaban, not only regarding the substance but also in terms of procedure, because she has done so in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We would also like to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The objective of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of drug safety once they have been marketed, particularly with regard to their risk profiles and any adverse reactions they may produce.

It is important to note the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will assess and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

It is very important the solution that has been reached for the notification to pharmacovigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by Member States and by the responsible parties for the marketing of medicines.

...Eudra Vigilance will be the sole source of information......but the competent authority......of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected......will also be notified, and this is very important...
It is also necessary to highlight the possibility that opens for consumers to communicate any adverse reaction, and in this sense, the creation and management by the agency of an ecological portal.
The European system for drug safety, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help to improve citizens' knowledge of the safety of the medicines they consume.
And finally, we must not forget that, given that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in protecting public health, the approval of the directive and the
This directive and regulation will contribute notably to this by improving not only current procedures, but also the coordination of actions among the various Member States.
Thank you, Mr. President.

On that occasion, we will seek to achieve a more balanced position than the one we have today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
I commend those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and members of parliament of this Parliament.
It has taken a financial crisis of enormous dimensions for Europe to awaken.

before similar authorities of Member States, and it is regrettable that progress has not been made towards an integration similar to that which occurred with the system of central banks.
We have made progress, but it is necessary to continue climbing the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for having allowed ETA terrorists to disappear.

...they are being trained in Venezuelan dreams…
under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubilla…
who works for the government of Hugo Chávez…
despite the fact that there is against him…
an international arrest warrant…
being this a serious violation…
of the fundamental right to security…
of any European citizen…
I demand from the Government of Spain a firm action in response to this serious humiliation of all Spaniards.
The shoemaker cannot continue to remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guard torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
nor can it turn a blind eye to this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as already denounced by Judge Eloy Velasco.
Zapatero cannot shake the hand of a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should provide a response, the one it deserves and the one any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroups would convene only on Thursdays.
Since then, we have attempted to resolve this matter.
We did not achieve it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, must convene on an unsuitable date…
They never have rooms and they never have interpretation.

Today, I speak not only as president of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but with the mandate of the majority of intergroups in this House, and therefore, of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and rescind the decision of February 14, 2008, and revert to the previous status of freedom for the intergroups.
And if you do not, I say gently as well that we will bring the matter to the full assembly of this House, and it will be decided who within this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, International Day against Trafficking in Persons for Exploitation convened data that should compel us to act with skepticism.
More than 90% of prostitution practiced in Europe originates from blackmail and extortion.

And in light of these data, we should ask ourselves if we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not speaking of the oldest profession in the world, but of the only form of slavery we have failed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and facilitating rehabilitation plans for women who are victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next directive on treatment is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to hinder the ease of access that exists, for example, in the offer to advertise across all types of media. ...we have an opportunity...
I call the attention of this Parliament to remain at the forefront of citizens’ rights.
Thank you, Madam President. We all agree that the diplomatic service represents a historic opportunity for European construction.

However, this requires acting with a broad vision, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term, nor for wars between the various European institutions.
What is now required, conversely, is to establish a general vision of what the European Union should be in the world. That is to say, to do precisely the opposite of what has been done in the past.
that occurred a few days ago on the occasion of the Nobel Peace Prize award, where too many voices have been heard from Europe, and not all of them courageous.
