Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance to the future of a sector—the cutlery and related industries—that in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of more than 8,000 jobs, an element of identity and a forward-looking commitment to craftsmanship as a source of employment generation.

It is the case that the Meidín sealing on knives has long been advocated by social groups such as Aprecu and contested by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to the transparency of commercial rules and the fight against unfair competition.

to increase consumers’ decision-making capacity when selecting a product, so that they consider not only the final price of the product itself, but also the brand's quality, the place of origin, or the social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are struggling, but who today look to us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for a fairer trade, yes, but also for giving added value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
Therefore, I thank the opponent and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and their social awareness on this important matter for my region.
Thank you, Mr. President. Let’s see if I can bring a little calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that certain countries and some of the states that comprise it continue to be present at this G20 forum, alongside the European Union.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe’s image in the world, it would be beneficial if at least a unified global position existed in that global forum.
And what, in my opinion, would that common position be?

In my modest opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not merely a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for the future.

to prevent market turbulence from dragging us down and causing us to repeat the errors committed throughout the 20th century. Thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and human freedoms.
public
In summary, it is important to understand that in the global world, in this global game, loses whoever plays only national cards.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe we are in the case of congratulating the rapporteur, Ms. Meisner.
There were distinct, established positions, and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.

Honorable members, the Transportation Committee has decided that all bars should be afforded similar protection, and to that end, it asserts that failure to do so would create an unfair competitive situation.

We accept the position of the majority in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not fail to point out to your lordships that it also represents a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea, and the English Channel are more polluted areas, and that controls on sulfur limit values should be more rigorous in those cases.
It is necessary to positively value the measures related to ports regarding their impact on solutions for reducing transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have an outstanding matter.
Without a decisive liberalization of ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they must play within the context of multimodality.
Welcome, too, esteemed members, the impetus for a strategy aimed at modifying the city’s specific climate change repercussions.
I believe this is a positive report that should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs within the context of a serious disaster, namely, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

And in that respect, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the revision of the European Maritime Safety Agency’s regulation strengthens the Agency’s role in prevention inspections and subsequent oil spill cleanup operations.
My personal assessment, Madam Commissioner, is that yes, and that those tasks must be reinforced with whatever mandate is necessary for that purpose.

Thank you, President. Integrated maritime policy is a cross-sectoral, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and agriculture, and which should not be subordinated to other policies.
We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both to society in general and to the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing techniques, species development, a maritime economy plan.

For greater utilization, quality supplies, international relations that avoid piracy, and to foster the governance of our seas—seas without barriers and free from sustainability issues, as has been the case in Iceland.

This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy.
This would be working towards the environment and sustainability.
Recently, the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows was attacked in Baghdad, and 58 people were murdered, most of them women and children solely for being Christians.
Al-Qaeda has proudly claimed responsibility for the feat.
It is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks against Christians in countries with a predominantly Muslim faith.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Buseca has made an institutional statement.
The High Representative, Mr. Ashton’s, statement of condemnation has been limited to condemning a terrorist act.
Why isn't the mobile phone mentioned? The condition of being Christian, which is the unequivocal cause of the slaughter.
I hear nothing from Mr. Zapatero. I have heard nothing from President Erdoğan.
What is the purpose of the Alliance of Civilizations?
I feel sorrow for our paternalism and our cowardice.

I am inevitably reminded of the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in the complex Europe.
Thank you also to the lady commissioner. I share the desire of this Chamber.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to receive the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is important to underscore the role of cities in environmental preservation.
There exists a pact among more than a thousand mayors in the European Union, demonstrating the recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are decisive if we are to succeed.
Grand words are of no use if we do not have the collaboration of city mayors.
To this end, it is essential to disseminate emissions data, as cities produce nearly 80% of greenhouse gases.
Currently, this dissemination does not exist, nor, worse still, a common pattern for the measurement of these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies, and I believe it could also be utilized by municipalities.
Without their participation, without the participation of these municipalities and their mayors, the environmental action dissolves into smoke, the very smoke we aim to escape.

Thank you, President. Some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the magnitude of the human rights repression in the Western Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or any legal title whatsoever.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate its violence.
Yesterday, I was speaking about the International Court of Justice in this very Parliament.

The international community, which tragically failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, hopes to avoid it in Western Sahara, however, and that we do not have to witness it before another court, also in The Hague as I was saying, but this time for war crimes.
President, Commissioner, the directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction because it points us toward the path to follow, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the monitoring mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic, ECMR, fragrances, and other hazardous substances such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary that the guidelines to be followed be clearer regarding the warning concerning the minimum age and the dangers resulting from inappropriate use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of child behavior.
We must be capable of adapting our regulations to scientific advances supported by solid studies and be more rigorous in the surveillance of the market and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among Member States and to rely on the joint efforts of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to make their holiday purchases, and we must assure them that the products they buy comply with all safety requirements.
that in this debate we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The various political groups have shown their support for this directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder, what impediment exists to approving this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there that something as necessary and straightforward as protecting victims equally across Europe might finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will largely approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations. And I applaud the Commission’s recognition of our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

Therefore, we must not exclude ourselves, but rather assist one another, approving this more concrete instrument today. Tomorrow, the commission will present a broader package of measures to aid victims, with which I pledge to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today, and let us help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let us help everyone, I repeat, be they men, women, or children.
Let us help those who look to us today, expecting us to provide them with a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their safety, and above all, their dignity.

Mr. President, the European People's Party group will vote enthusiastically in favor of this report, and my congratulations first to the rapporteurs, the committee, and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, the term democratic deficit in the 1980s.
With him, we wanted to say that in the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers on proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was consulted only.
The battle of this Parliament, since the 1980s, through the Treaty of Maastricht, of Amsterdam, of Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Treaty of Lisbon, has been…

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we conclude today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament during the Convention’s proceedings.

And I want to recall here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German social democratic colleague, and Anand Lamassur, who were the ones who brought that initiative to the convention floor and ensured its approval.
Therefore, I believe we have completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have put, laid on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now our turn, esteemed members, to act responsibly. And today, we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the EU budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.

In January 2012, as many as 400 Spanish egg producers could disappear, representing approximately 30% of the total in my country. This would entail the loss of a production output of 300,000 tons of eggs.

And the European Union could cease producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only succeed in having them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are significantly lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This directive from 1999, which mandates increasing the space within battery cages for laying hens, requires us to act with intelligence and a proactive vision, because if not...

We will only succeed in weakening European production and giving extra, commercial opportunities to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than that which we currently have in the European Union.

It is a directive that requires enormous efforts from European producers. In Spain alone, we can see that the cost rises to approximately 600 million euros. However, it is also important not to forget that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore request the support of the honorable members for the Popular Group’s amendment to the second paragraph, where it is requested to seek a solution, at the very least, for responsible operations, of responsible industrialists, who are proceeding with the transformation of their operations and who by January 2012 will be nearing completion.

We must support them in transforming those facilities and give them time to finalize that process, thus avoiding irreparable harm to the farms and preventing a sudden shortage in the community market, consequently increasing prices for consumers.
It is a matter of respecting the directive, of giving an opportunity to the egg and ovoproduct industry, while also respecting animal welfare rights and consumers’ right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only right to thank the rapporteurs, especially Ms. Grostet and Ms. Dagmar Romberen from my own group, for the work they have done in breaking the deadlock and transforming this regulation into a useful one, because this work has enabled the inclusion of the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that will guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at every moment. Especially because it also allows for a clear regulation of the role of States, both those of origin that must make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not feel satisfied with that alone, but rather that this must be the beginning of a much greater advance that, as Mrs. Romberen said, makes this directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all states renders unnecessary the displacement of each citizen to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that more effectively guarantees the rights of citizens in relation to the care, benefits, assimilation, and security they are entitled to, rather than the mere right they already have to mobility between States.
Equality is what will unite us, or we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here feeling entirely comfortable without making clear my concern that this directive includes…
the matter of organ transplants against the opinion held by the Environment Committee as a result of the Council’s persistent insistence on including transplants in this directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very session, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, just recently and with near-total support.

I note that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not diminish the excellent work carried out by such successful organizations as the Spanish National Transplant Organization, and certainly with the intention of saving 20,000 lives, which we had both in the transplant directive and in the Action Plan, which I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will continue to monitor compliance with this directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Day for Sexual Health.
Esteemed colleagues, the data are concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over 300 million people unknowingly contract a sexually transmitted infection each year.

In Europe, as the European Forum for Sexual Health warns, the increase in unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is concerning due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our young people.

Even, as the Commission points out, there are distinct and diverse inequalities in access to sexual health services across European countries and, within those countries, according to citizens’ income levels.
To address all of this, a European strategy is necessary.
Only five Member States have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unintended pregnancies, sexually transmitted infections, and abortions has been reduced.

A common strategy that prioritizes prevention within the educational sphere, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of every citizen to sexual health under the safest and most hygienic conditions.
In times of heightened social tensions, one cannot help but warmly welcome the major social consensus agreement in Spain between the government, trade unions, and employers' organizations.
This agreement serves as a model for Europe, where such milestones have not been achieved for quite some time.

It is also important to consider the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the principal protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8th.
Cándido then insisted on the necessity of extending conciliation at the European level and on the need to include the voice and initiatives of trade unions in this our Europe.
So it must be...

Thank you, President. Setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union moves, unfortunately, in response to emergency situations, such as a serious murder.

an attack or a massive influx of migrants like the one currently occurring in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens toward the Italian coast could result in a chronicle of a foretold death.
The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and weigh upon our consciences, upon those of all who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will clutch our heads in dismay, but the following day we will forget.

European citizens have both the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream, as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient economic means to make it effective.
Talking costs nothing, but one must act.
act. Do they genuinely believe that Frontex, in its current state, can guarantee security at Europe’s borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future en masse in Europe, but rather in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all truth when discussing a common European migration policy, one more necessary now than ever.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is striking that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equity among citizens are found in the area of pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost only 20% of their value in 2008 and that they continue, to this day, far from the solvency levels required.

All of this demonstrates that at a moment of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a transversal manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies regarding birth rates or work-life balance.

ambitious policies regarding access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that, from a demographic perspective, also guarantee the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not establish limits on the abuse of scholarship figures within companies, as these are generally excluded from all forms of social security contributions.

In my judgment, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers to whom, if a dignified pension is being demanded through increased effort, it would also be necessary to make it less arduous to access a decent job.

President, Commissioner, we find ourselves at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion seeks harmonious development among territories to ensure that citizens can fully leverage their unique territorial characteristics.
However, to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to advance cooperation among regions of the Union facing similar challenges and issues.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union’s Strategy for the Atlantic Region. A common perspective for addressing the common challenges faced by the region’s States. Among others, marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is aligned with the 2020 Strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period following 2013, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
However, esteemed members, it is first and foremost necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multilevel governance, founded on closer engagement of public authorities.
regional and local, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to discuss equality between men and women, because we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, 100 years ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women’s suffrage.
We have advanced considerably in these 100 years, but much remains to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and the discrimination of women is a real fact.

I believe each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women. Because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and my hope to all the women in the North African revolution who are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half as much as a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere else in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it. And as long as that equality does not exist, International Women’s Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to acknowledge it, it is a reality that women earn half as much as men, and that domestic violence disproportionately affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue denouncing these events in this Parliament, and I certainly promise that I will continue working.
Thank you, Mr. President. I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the members of parliament who have spoken this morning here and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on whether the European Council is willing to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
because the new mechanism, concerning which we are speaking, must be an important component of the economic governance led by a European Union.
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is to say, we must avoid at all costs this endeavor in which we are engaged ending up in the intergovernmental channel, which is a dead end or the channel of dominance by a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforces and balances this delicate edifice.
Essential points remain to be improved, therefore we must return the report to the committee.
The person who concluded the parliamentary process for this report is unknown.
The initial proposal was poor.
That is what consumer associations were telling us, both at the national and European levels.
And I particularly value the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacia Alonso.
We have managed to ensure the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4 was rejected.

It must be stated clearly that maximum harmonization when establishing the same protection in all Member States would entail a lowering of protection for many consumers, as there exists in various countries a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, however, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Shift the burden of proof to the individual clauses. Therefore, it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses deviating from the generally established terms have been individually negotiated. That contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and comprehensible form.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization with respect to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of retailers believe that full harmonization in this area will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Thank you, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, allow me first to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Swab, and Ms. Gerhard, for the excellent work carried out.
and a general reflection.
It is not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that the aim is to avoid reducing rights already existing in some of the Member States.
Because if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must establish
Establish concurrently a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance requires agreeing to a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community measure to mean the unprotected status of many consumers and users.
I welcome the improvement in negotiations within the European Parliament, but I would like to stress that rights already established should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis, and that either we are not doing the necessary work to avoid it, or we are not doing so at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is issuing a call for everyone to make a small gesture in the interest of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will follow suit.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue depending on energies that are not its own, that are distant, or on insecure energies.
We must help the States build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new environment.
We must also support raising awareness of new consumption guidelines, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiencies are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to make an appeal to all countries of the Union to join that appeal, that willingness of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because in doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a leader in freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Thank you very much. Most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and once again I am here to combat it.

I must say that I not only do not tire of this, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best suited for it.

I have this platform available to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel the States to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that one-quarter of European women have experienced gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to demand greater commitment as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to continue insisting again and again, to protect victims as we already did with the European Protection Order for Victims, of which I was rapporteur, and which I hope becomes a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that when it comes to addressing domestic violence affecting all members of the
Family, children, elderly people, women, and men should not be a cause for political opportunism, as it is to all of our honor to advance the solution of this social scourge.
First, it is imperative to speak out, and second, to get to work, for even though we have been discussing gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something must be going wrong, and therefore it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to action, providing more tangible assistance and the necessary attention so that women can live with dignity and security.
safety. Let all victims know that I will always be here, continuing to lend them my voice until, together, we defeat this.
terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough now, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Thank you very much, President. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and restore confidence in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

because with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward toward the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also respond to the demands of citizens who call for advancing toward greater Europe and strengthening social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a social market economy, highly competitive, that fosters sustainable growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market. That puts citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to request that the Commission submit these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, consequently, to our public health.

A disease against which we fought through an activated vaccine, the use of which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal circulation, because the use of these vaccines can provoke an undesired circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine, the application of vaccination, was limited to those areas where animals had previously been found infected, creating a twofold detriment for ranchers. On the one hand, the disease, and on the other hand, the restrictions.

However, all these problems appear to be preventable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disturbances that can be provoked in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies—which is truly the most important aspect of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all of these reasons, it is of vital importance to this sector that we modify the directive to permit its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Honorable members, compliance with what our treaties stipulate, particularly regarding the correlation tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into effect before summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming the livestock farmers.

Firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has undertaken following the complaint submitted by FEPEX, the Spanish Organisation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of that report are perfectly clear and more than sufficiently justify the European Commission having already set to work long ago to clarify the operation of the entry pricing system, at least with respect to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to resolve potential loopholes that the current price regulation may give rise to, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without previously addressing the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Honorable Members, it is now time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and begin investigating where fraud occurs, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that a new agreement with Morocco should in no way be ratified without the details we have outlined being resolved.

Our objective is not to hinder the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that said agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules established in those agreements are respected.

Regarding the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector is only requesting guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed-upon measures will be carried out. And this is only possible through the reform of the current import pricing regime.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the committee has already finalized.

Furthermore, if control is the responsibility of the Member States, a significant economic effort should be required of them. However, it is also true that we have long been calling for a European customs frontier system, modeled after that of the United States, to ensure effective control.

Thank you, President. Commissioner, addressing this report in Parliament has been complex, primarily because it involves these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization and the preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan. We understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided they take into account the sensitivities of the
European industry and, particularly, the textile sector, which in regions such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely affected by the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade likely cannot be addressed with the urgency these acts require; therefore, we must learn from this for the future.

Will it help Pakistan? Yes, but not with the Commission’s original proposals, as they do not take into account the effects of the European industry regarding the implementation timelines for sensitive and immunocompromised products.
It would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not align with the pending text expected to be approved by the WTO. We would be out of time.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal, and we believe we will have to vote against it.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating everyone who has made reaching an agreement possible.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves on, as it affects the daily life of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few observations.
First, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing information that is accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and consistent.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Extensive information will be of no use if citizens are subsequently unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary but insufficient step. We should advance further and protect citizens who may be more vulnerable.
Distinguished members, it is essential to establish a European sizing system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing an item of clothing is the size.
Therefore, we should be far more ambitious and seek the harmonization of sizes.
Mr. President, three observations regarding the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have a great fondness for that country, but it is evident that German authorities have acted in this case with undue haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European action, we observe that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been lackluster, very muted, and imprecise. It has not known how to coordinate or direct.
Thirdly, those harmed have the right to prompt economic compensation.
But for the moment, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a large exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
One must reclaim lost honor, a phrase pleasing to the German writer Heinrich Bell. One must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for it.
First, sincere regret is obligatory for the 23 victims already deceased, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be said to be the most compelling proof that the European Union must significantly improve its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The member states involved have demonstrated slowness, ineffectiveness, and inaction, and at this point, even after 23 deaths, we still do not know the source of the problem.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present, leading to cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were formerly essential.

of unemployment, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the commission, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities

very ill-informed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish holdings. Meanwhile, the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria. Believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to consuming something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council meeting being held in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to the ministers that a portion of the 2.5 billion euros existing as unused carryover funds from the common agricultural policy be utilized.
those 2.5 billion euros to repair as much as possible the damage caused.

To that end, it is necessary to seek a legal hook that allows for it. A legal hook that has already been found on other occasions, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, commissioners, ministers, you must be worthy of your responsibility here in Luxembourg today.

German authorities, furthermore, given the irresponsible accusations leveled, should support this economic solution without doubt and from the outset. And they should also fund, with their own resources, communication campaigns to reestablish consumer trust lost in horticultural produce. Thank you.

Mr. President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and I hope that what is being done prevents there from being more and stops the chain of sufferers who are enduring this without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes, certainly, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions, and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state from another continent.

The arrogance displayed by Mrs. Merkel and her Minister of Health in their unusually frequent appeals to other states, had it been translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordinating efforts, some of the events that have transpired would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a State that has been the Spanish State and for the most important sector of agriculture. It has led to familial ruin for thousands of people and small business owners and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I request that you go to the Council and request total compensation for those affected, since we cannot demand life from the deceased.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
and that responsibility be demanded of Mrs. Merkel
And that less arrogance and more diligence be requested of him.
and that he be held responsible for damages he has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is within your state.
cannot ignore its responsibilities.
It cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to inflict the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little more sound management, and a little less conservatism would have served very well to prevent this crisis from spiraling out of control, so that Spain and other farmers in the south would not have had to suffer its grievous consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability because we are requesting it of you, Commissioner, of the Council, and of the German State, here in Spain.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response, someone has been sought as the guilty party, if not the cause itself.

The system has not functioned. We have 22 deaths, 1,600 affected individuals, and we still do not know the cause three weeks later. And appealing to a principle of precaution without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is being blamed.
Honorable members of parliament, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were not contaminated. I repeat this because contrary versions have been heard here.
But so you can understand the importance of what these words have sparked, 300,000 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner. It knows no borders. We demand accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately. Because Germany has a risk problem at the moment. It has a higher number of affected individuals, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
And what unites us here today is the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers do today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

It is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers and, specifically, the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería – which were model farms – and that these will not recover from those accusations.
Thousands of families without work wonder why. Why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be. Not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will rapidly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, request immediate economic and moral measures for all producers from Andalusia and from across Europe who look to us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing research and European collaboration, German authorities have defamed and harmed cucumber producers and others.
and has yet to dismiss anyone in Germany nor offer reparations commensurate with the damage caused,
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
The treatment of the southern countries by Mrs. Merkel regarding both agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that. Credit default. Morality.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and perhaps another country share our reservations about readily accepting the so-called Brovilleta.

The coincidence, the criticism, stems from our condition as peripheral countries, ultimately meaning we will be the ones paying this singular levy that the states of the European Union with central geographic location will collect.
The rationale inspiring the eurocomic is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting discourse grows increasingly tenuous.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, ultimately it does not hold that congestion should be alleviated by penalizing only heavy-duty vehicles while excluding passenger cars, in the same way that the old principle of “polluter pays” is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, esteemed members, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately allocate only 15% to the financing of trans-European networks and not in a mandatory manner.

but as a simple recommendation. In such a manner that the minister of finance on duty will allocate the collected funds to the purpose he deems most convenient for the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing more than another setback for the transportation of goods by road, which today is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in a context of economic crisis.

In that sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot permit experiments that could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy through the imposition of additional costs.

The food crisis recklessly imposed on Spanish products has resulted in an unjust penalty and substantial losses for those penalized by the euro vignette: carriers of goods and farmers of primary crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, for which the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all, dear colleagues, understand that upon assuming the presidency of this session, I wish to express my sorrow and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Semprún, we celebrate one who was imprisoned in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable, committed writer, a particular contributor to our program, The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death, both as a colleague and friend. I will ask President Budgec to send a message of heartfelt condolences and solidarity to his family and the Government of Spain, a sentiment I am certain we all share.
creation of a governance space for economic affairs governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We cannot continue to turn a blind eye.
It is inconsistent to have a single currency while simultaneously lacking the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency demands.
Specifically, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a resounding no to competition between the debt issuances of the Member States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonization of tax policies that guarantee the equality of citizens, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, it will be said, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated, because no one listens to them.
And precisely because of not listening, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are unfolding.

Thank you very much, President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen. The current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing underscores the need for regional policy as the most effective instrument for reducing disparities in development between regions and states.
At the same time, we can reclaim the positive image of Europe that citizens lately only associate with harsh austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of European solidarity and social justice, must take the following priorities into account. First, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy. Second, to consider the needs and characteristics that have arisen within the project.

Third, to maintain the principle of graduality in the allocation of funds, so that regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding abrupt changes in the receipt of aid. And fourth, to promote an efficient system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, authorities are implementing stringent austerity measures.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes due note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I urge the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The tribunal president stated that I was selected to support the peace process. And as far as I know, in Spain there exists a terrorist organization called ETA that to this day has not abandoned its arms and that two months ago managed to have its political arm, Bildu, govern, among other municipalities, San Sebastián.

I do not believe that from Europe, we should grant such a powerful platform to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to apportion blame between victims and perpetrators.
Murderers? Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues—such as Mayor Oreja and Turgay, Salva, or myself—must travel under escort.
I believe in a culture of life, not a culture of shooting. The Lord
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián is a city free for all, may it present its candidacy once more. And in the meantime, let them learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
because tomorrow perhaps they will deserve it, but today with Batasuna and its successors in the institutions they do not deserve it.
Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided in drafting this document.
And the same I say with respect to the other deputy colleagues of the Commission of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. Few things are better to commemorate this event than to debate now about energy infrastructure in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy: a common European internal market, the promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument in the fight against climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.

In the Treaty of Lisbon, a chapter has been dedicated to energy, Chapter 21, where these commitments I have mentioned are formulated, as well as the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.

Consequently, the objective of the report we have prepared is oriented toward correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we observe a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south of
Europe and in North Africa, with the problems stemming from large-scale electricity storage, with the needs for electric vehicle recharging, among many other pressing issues.
All of this is impossible to face today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

Therefore, in the coming years, the focus will be on advancing the determination of necessary infrastructure. A. Establishing the criteria that allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b. Suppressing energetic islands.
c. Ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and arbitrating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the projects.
D. Ensuring financing that attracts and stimulates private investment without prejudice to the public support that may be necessary.

Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report because we have ensured that the report is a significant benefit to health.
I believe that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be diminished, with the consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A primary concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to enable the execution of the necessary works.
Currently, they are prolonged indefinitely.
and they are prolonged by the opposition of populations to seeing towers or facilities of another type grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to providing early information to citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that authorities in a State fail to address a request within a reasonable timeframe.
We face ambitious goals that require the involvement of everyone.
In this regard, companies in the sector are essential, rightfully calling for a stable regulatory framework, the best way to secure funding for their endeavors.
Until now, the European Union’s energy policy, both towards countries outside its borders and within its own territory, has lacked a distinctly European impetus.
Europe speaking with a single voice, a voice that is clearly audible and resonates fully within the dome of the European building, because it is from our energy fragility that we have disappeared.
to summon the strength to build a Europe that is energetically robust and vigorous, a worthy successor this anniversary year to that great invention that was the ECSC, our cradle precisely.
Mr. President, whenever there is a commitment that allows for progress, one should congratulate oneself, but I don't believe the commitment we have reached warrants a fit of euphoria.
We must be prudent in the moments of happiness we seize.

It is true that we have made progress, particularly with regard to food labeling, especially concerning safety and the clarity of the message, but we have fallen short regarding trans fats and, for example, the obligation to label them.
What I do want to ask the committee is that it not exhaust the deadlines.

Account audits today are burdened by the concentration of firms and the lack of auditor independence, and they do not contribute to generating that much-desired trust that would revitalize our economy.
It would not be unreasonable to consider eliminating the legal obligation for account audits.
Why not?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and within the markets, we must undertake a profound reform of audits so that they represent a genuine added value and not merely a legal burden.
Large auditing firms leverage auditing services as a calling card for their prospective clients.
Once familiar with the company, they offer more costly complementary services to often compensate for the low prices of the strict audit.
We have a price distortion problem in the sector.

These complementary services now account for nearly 50% of billing, which is why major audit firms do not want to lose audit services, but not for the audit itself, but rather to maintain and expand the complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four large companies that dominate European markets by over 90%.
As such, oligopolies control prices and establish barriers to entry for new competitors, leveraging intangibles such as Marx’s international image.

It is true that this brand image can be founded on certain advantages, but it does not always equate to greater efficiency, given the diversity of legislative frameworks in the accounting standards subject to particular treatment in each member state.
I share the objectives of the green book—independence and concentration within the sector—and the means to be employed: rotation, audits, joint ventures.
