There are still many things to do.
We must improve safety nets and make them more agile and more effective.
We must continue to strengthen the sector's integration within the value chain, ensure equitable allocation of quotas—particularly in certain regions—and promote a quality policy.

But without any doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B has rightly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which expands quotas for certain horticultural products, is absolutely meaningless when the figures in the present agreement are not respected.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters reported to this very Parliament’s petitions committee the massive influx of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price below that stipulated in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must respect rigorous environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always adhere to.
To conclude, I will point out the matter of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
It also constitutes a zone over which the United Nations does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, adherence to international law must be ensured.

I support an agreement with Morocco, an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices. An agreement that combats dumping, that does not exploit the Moroccan farmer, and above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
This agreement is not, strictly speaking, that.

In the fourth year, the European Parliament’s Committee on Petitions requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the pricing system for the entry of fruits and vegetables into the Union, a system that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union’s Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF.
Primarily, they are Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request has been echoed in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This fraud is remedied by modifying the implementing regulations of the Common Organisation of Markets in Agricultural Products, because aligning the Customs Code does not resolve the issue, Commissioner.

For several years, within the Popular Party, I have advocated for the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to guarantee compliance with the existing agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States who must guarantee the control of imports.

However, what the Commission fails to mention is that the entry price system is in effect, and this system prevents national customs authorities from accurately tracking the prices declared by importers to verify whether any irregularities exist.

Amend the implementing regulations of the Common Organisation of Markets for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem. Because if not, the legal loophole in European legislation prevents national authorities from performing their work correctly.
Not enrolled.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, attempting to create an anticipation that diminishes daily.
They are ceasing to be credible because they do not contribute to resolving the crisis.
Peaks at which the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

It should be known that as long as progress is not made in political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In telegraphic form, two ideas. The first, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is being built, the second [authorization] to immediately permit the utilization of structural funds that remain unallocated.
These amounts could comfortably offset the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Thank you, Madam President. From the European Parliament, I wish today to pay tribute to all women, who, despite the considerable progress made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and improved working conditions, I believe that gender equality remains a distant goal.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone’s permission, but in many cases they continue to earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
It is also necessary to remember women in rural areas, whose labor is overlooked.
I believe another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Already this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats made by those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims’ Directive presented by the Commission, which, God willing, will be voted on next June.
We must also say, and I would like to emphasize, that motherhood remains an obstacle to women's advancement, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to launch a message of hope, and with many women, with the help of an increasing number of men, we must advance on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights, and also of responsibilities.
We have come a long way, but there is much yet to be done.
I must admit that I do not absolutely or deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something must be done, and I agree with
Many of my colleagues, and of course with Mrs. Reding, for opening this debate and moving forward on this path so that women regain the place they deserve, and on that you can count on my support.

Mr. President. At a juncture of economic crisis and budget cuts that is impacting both public healthcare and in which, as is the case in the community where I live, research centers such as Príncipe Felipe, specializing in diabetes, are being deprived of funding, this resolution comes at a better time than ever. It is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a recommendation from the Council stating that Member States must increase research, even with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs promoting healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In sum, we must prioritize the health of people above all else, and in this case, investigate, coordinate, and implement national programs coordinated by the Commission and demanding results regarding diabetes, to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and to guarantee their own lives.

If we dedicate more money to this, some will take a little longer to be reimbursed. But undoubtedly, those who are currently experiencing problems will have a higher quality of life, and we, as States, as Council, and as Commission, will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to safeguard the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many matters this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market—a market that was, certainly, born with defects.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. That is to say, this price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all of the European Union’s green policy.
If emission rights are not valued, it is incentivizing the increase in emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques. And worse yet,
The funding of significant projects will be jeopardized, such as, for example, those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage facilities.
This is the risk.
It falls to us, to the Commission, and to the Parliament to bring it about.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has scarcely begun with the experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent necessity.
The members of parliament have verified this firsthand during a visit to the Iraqi refugee camps originating in Syria. Also, the news that quickly reached us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our opponent, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with such tenacity as Ruiz Tavares.
He has fought to ensure that the European Parliament maintains the new powers gained following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the sustained work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would also have been impossible.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be utilized as soon as possible, now that they are so greatly needed.
Finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope we can also give you and your kind heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package next month.

The European social model we so proudly champion is not solely founded on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a particular understanding of the balance between employer and worker within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government, without dialogue and without consensus, breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both with regard to job creation and with regard to its quality.
Labor reform by itself does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define under what conditions workers enter companies, under what conditions they remain within them, and under what conditions they leave them.

And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective bargaining agreements, where they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company revenue,
They may unilaterally modify their schedules. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which undermines the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to workers’ conditions, deserves a general strike such as the one that must be convened tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let me state at the outset that the Spanish delegation of the European People’s Party considers both packages presented today to be correct and endorses them—both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely linked to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events each day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
It has become inevitably necessary to refocus attention on Spain.
Unjustified alarms have been triggered in the markets, partly encouraged by statements, in my opinion, Mr. President, that were untimely.
Some, within the context of significant elections where each contender cites my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
We certainly do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some, in order to deflect attention from their own problems, also concern themselves with us in a rather undiplomatic manner.
Today, here either, some have not been gracious, as the Italians would say, and there has been some lack of political finesse.
Esteemed members, the state of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with the full capacity to meet its debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Never, Mr. Esbóvaga, has Mr. Rajoy said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He said the opposite, that he is willing to fulfill all of his objectives, and he reiterates this every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt ambitious measures to guarantee fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improvement in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF’s forecasts, incidentally, from yesterday, the IMF itself acknowledges, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures adopted by the Spanish Government currently.
Other measures we have adopted. State General Budgets for 2012, which, in our judgment, will ensure that the deficit target is met this year. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability.

It will present a reform of education and healthcare, representing an adjustment of 10 billion euros. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to the requirement for financial institutions to provide over 50 billion euros.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves together, and Spain with all, without any doubt, and the criticisms of some or others contribute nothing to this. Either all of us countries are capable of being together and contributing to growth and a new path, or otherwise, it will naturally be difficult for us to move forward in the terms presented by the Commission.
Do you wish to feature Mr. Rajoy, the Prime Minister, as the central figure?
I have no objection; I would have no difficulty.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst legacy ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance any government has ever had.
President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to frame the issue.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and extends beyond that with that significant European value, which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments within original or derived Community law to neutralize the arbitrariness of Argentinian authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer my services to them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizenry is currently at stake.

Thank you, President. From the Committee on Agriculture, we share the ultimate objective of this directive: to attempt to guide, through fiscal imposition, the composition of our energy mixes. However, we are facing a very complex debate.

full of sharp angles in the economic, social, and environmental realms. What is important is maintaining those equilibria that allow us to advance further in the environmental sphere, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and do not create greater social crises than those we are already experiencing.
This is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs increasingly represent a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations. At a time when, moreover, we are engaged in a debate that combines crises in raw materials markets with a prospect of reduced subsidies and a focus on health and environmental concerns that impact their profitability margins.
...that is why we have fundamentally requested two things...

First, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and compliance with energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of the
Within the sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also access the permitted deductions in the CO2 emissions range.
That is to say, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains those equilibria that make our rural environment viable at a time of change and uncertainty within it.
We are experiencing a significant controversy that has austerity and growth as essential references.
If one hears the noise that is forming, it would seem that the idea of growth is a luminous invention of these days.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, a pact precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since 1997.

Therefore, a significant portion of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as those concerning regional cohesion and research, are policies aimed at growth and that pursue the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest opportunity to be heard, we harbor no reservations whatsoever when it comes to engaging in that debate, a debate we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the unaffiliated.

Thank you very much, President. Allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their assistance with this report, which has made it significantly stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.

Over these 20 years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and law that generate dynamism and security.
and trust. Transparency, a fundamental principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Bernier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework relating to the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both internal and external, complicates the adoption of a global legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability through a cross-sectional analysis, one that takes into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
As an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, the available options, or their lack of awareness of existing claims and compensation systems, particularly in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all of these reasons that, to address the deficiencies—that is, the problems—it is necessary to adopt a strategy of reinforcing vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures into their legislations to guarantee adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where a higher level of knowledge has been demonstrated and where the largest number of consumer complaints are recorded. The financial sector, whose complexity implies that any consumer potentially may be vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is requested to intensify its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, expanding on clear explanations and using straightforward language regarding the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising…

of foods high in fats, salt, and sugars, and to children and young people, who are the most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transportation sector, which often continues to face difficulties when vulnerable individuals travel. The energy and telecommunications sector,

where a lack of transparency can, in some cases, create an additional difficulty for consumers. For example, in the energy sector, when determining the tariff that best suits their needs. In access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing economic mechanisms.
existing.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are requested, and may I issue a word of caution to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr. Gallardón, to ensure that rights are not rolled back.
And let it proceed in a direction opposite to the march of these times of difficulty. To put intelligence and good governance in favor of an alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.

Finally, it is important to conclude that any of us are susceptible to becoming vulnerable consumers. Thank you very much, and I would like to express my gratitude to all the SADOS for the assistance provided in reinforcing this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The truth is, I have a feeling of hopelessness, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone.
will allow me to do so this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we’ve held in recent times in this Chamber regarding the situation of youth unemployment across Europe. And debate after debate. While youth unemployment rates are soaring in some Member States, we are already nearing 50%.

50% of the active population's rate, while many of them are already without any social or unemployment coverage, while all this is happening, while we transition from a situation that evolves from concerning to

Unsustainable and from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission appears once more in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true Government of the Union, which it is and moreover, which we need.
Mr. Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities, taking the initiative, and furthermore, with the aim of achieving some end, some objective, and furthermore, the commission is not doing so.

Governing is not a simple restructuring of funds, nor even announcing such a restructuring to improve public perception; it is about elevating an ambitious, enduring, and rapid strategy to eradicate youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate exceeding 20% and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we face.

To govern is not to yield to the pressures of the Board of Commissioners or of other Member States of the Council who strive to convince us that from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, we will only emerge by relinquishing wages, labor rights, or compensation; that only a future of precariousness awaits us as a generation.

Because if this were true, furthermore, Commissioner, that we only achieve competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, and it is not.
These are Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by exemplary models of labor relations and also by a model of labor guarantee rights.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizen’s right. It is an instrument of connection to the system, an instrument of social integration, and

Therefore, the more unemployment there is, the greater the political disaffection. And that is why, Commissioner, I will not accept your invoking matters of jurisdiction as an excuse for doing nothing regarding youth unemployment.

Because, furthermore, Commissioner, when it has been necessary to interpret the treaties leniently to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so. And when it has been necessary to reform the treaties to comply with or satisfy the delusions of some member state regarding austerity, we have also done so.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have, for example, the guarantee of youth employment. It is unnecessary to explain it to you.

Advocate for an increased budget. Utilize, if necessary, the European Social Fund as an instrument. Design an implementation mechanism with funding and solidarity that most assists those experiencing the highest unemployment rates. Press for further changes to this policy of social suffocation for countries that are faring the worst. And remember that behind each statistic is a person struggling.
Then, you will think as I do that the less important aspect is not whose competence it is, particularly for the citizenry as a whole.
Thank you, President. Commissioner, I thank the Interinstitutional Committee for the work done, the rapporteurs, and the shadow rapporteurs.

In general terms, we are dealing with a good S.G. Plus regulation that is necessary, specifically in certain actions relating to the control of import regulations for textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.

However, we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of the Systematic Program of Grants (SPG) for certain countries classified as upper-middle income. Countries, for example, like Latin America.
Because what about these middle-income countries with undiversified exports?
diversified? Why not introduce a diversification criterion into export strategy?

Because this could generate two different speeds. Countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a period of transition, and that amendments will be presented during this transitional period to adapt to this situation for these countries, and to provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they may benefit from it.

I already supported Mrs. Anadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the Congo mission together with other parliamentarians. And indeed, I observed few communities with a greater demonstrated will to establish and participate in democracy.
But a people to believe in democracy need also to believe in their State and their government. And that will not be possible merely through electoral support or external support.
They also need a commitment to fighting corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the world’s wealthiest countries in terms of resources.

It must be said and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or, at the very least, encouraged by those unscrupulous multinational corporations that, from Europe or other continents or states, are capable of participating in corruption without regard for fostering conflicts over those resources to win the favor of those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Mr. Astro, although it may not be strictly within your purview, I do maintain that greater demands for traceability and transparency from multinational European corporations and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as beneficial for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at the electoral and technical levels.
Mr. President, to the speakers for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating package 2, after having approved package 6, after almost all Heads of State and of Government agreed to two international treaties outside the constitutional order.
After numerous other European regulations have created additional Community authorities for banking supervision, securities regulation, insurance oversight, and systemic economic risk.
A proliferation of texts—reports, proposals—addressing new economic assessment criteria, new procedures, new processes.
Regarding procedures, we must not halt and apply what we have already approved.
Confronted by the instability experienced by the European continent, precisely the opposite is needed: stability and legal certainty.
We do not require a patchwork of successive legal findings.
I don’t know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation that the rescue entails is very concerning.
The citizens of Spain are not being told the whole truth regarding the new debt, whereby the Spanish government and State are assuming private debt as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously stated it did not want, presenting it ludicrously as a triumph, something a colleague in this debate had already cautioned.
There is no triumph, only failure, with Bankia and others.

I insist, there is no further politically correct approach for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must coalesce. For we will not escape debt without harmonious growth for all and as a whole.

Supervision as requested in the two reports, certainly, all the supervision that is necessary, but also essential, simultaneous growth, anti-speculative as well, and also as alluded to in some of the measures in both reports and other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency as well, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo was saying earlier.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls worldwide. 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.

...an unbearable figure......for anyone who pauses to study......the terrible consequences......of these practices......hidden under the guise......of psychological, health, or religious reasons......all of them false...

The truth is that ablation, practiced preferentially on girls of 14 and even one year of age, can lead to death due to hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights that undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Esteemed members, this concerns abuse, cruelty, and torture against girls. And this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To that end, we must activate all the preventive mechanisms available to our legal system, and I urge our judges to act to prevent female genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who perpetrate it. May the law in Europe speak with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I urge civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still much road to travel, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector towards a market without milk quotas in 2015.

However, it is also true that as this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty within the sector grows due to the lack of a clear exit strategy. The reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection regarding the decision we face also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or sugar quotas, at least until 2020. Reasons like the uncertainty that exists within the sector regarding the real effects of the dairy package and whether

...that we will have had time to make a serious assessment of them... and reasons as well, such as the uncertainty regarding the direction of the common agricultural policy... and especially its budget, that is, the portion of income... that does not come from the markets and which affects our producers.

Therefore, what is it that we are requesting, Commissioner? That you convey this to Mr. Cholos. That we not implement a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

defer the end of the quota until 2015, until a date that provides security for the sector and opens a transparent and open debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets are still more unfair and producers are increasingly defenseless.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Many members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizenry, the voice of the streets.
Mr. Commissioner, you have said this is a take-it-or-leave-it agreement.
We members of this Parliament, too, bear responsibility for the yes or the no.
And we say no because this agreement produces confusion, as is evident.
Intellectual property rights and internet user rights are not clarified.
Are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
Yes.
Yes, it is an effective solution.
No, it is not a solution. Because there are two matters to address. It is not a legal matter, but two political ones. One, the determination of the struggle against forgery and perversion.
piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment that we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist group, and we are requesting it again.
It is your opportunity.
Do not turn your back on society, because tomorrow it may shrink and you will have no recourse.
Improve; it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The feeling of helplessness was of such magnitude that Europe was compelled to react. And it has done so for the benefit of all. Because the great winner of this past summit has been the euro.
With this victory, hope has returned that Europe will overcome its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
In this summit, ladies and gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to guarantee financial stability as long-term measures to address the Union’s deficiencies.
In this instance, the immediate was essential to continue working on what was important.
The imperative result is to launch a message stating that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as significant as empowering the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will allow us to break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt—a thesis consistently defended, incidentally, by the current Spanish Government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that fulfill their commitments regarding public deficits and reforms.
Those were necessary decisions to guarantee financial stability, which must be the European Union's top priority in the short term.
It is not this time, esteemed members, for certain countries to resort to nationalist rhetoric and erect obstacles.
I have already said it; it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing, in record time, the most ambitious reform agenda of Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, a financial reform is underway, predicated on complete transparency, demonstrating a commitment to fiscal consolidation and the fulfillment of deficit objectives.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process toward greater economic integration through four blocs, a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic agility.
Mr. President, the community acts first and then Europe has always been not only to endure crises, but to emerge strengthened from them.
I am pleased that we have once again succeeded.
Dear colleagues, our full attention is focused on banks, of which we repeatedly hear described as the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being stated this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.
And it is also an opportunity to promote the issuance of privately held debt guaranteed by European institutions, specifically intended for these purposes and openly accessible to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear support of these projects.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, Minister, in which I offer my greetings to the new presidency, I am a veteran activist of the defunct Non-Aligned Movement that your country led, and which earnestly desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Honorable members, it was necessary to seize the opportunity for a broader reform of the Tribunal, perhaps, but the ambition of the Commission and my colleague rapporteur are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity they enjoyed in our Committee.
The agility and proper functioning of the Tribunal are essential... which I question with the currently delayed patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the speaker. Proceed with the reform of the court.

Thank you, President, Commissioner Reding. My country has experienced too many setbacks since the People's Party took office. Repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing dissenters—including consumer organizations, among others—have occurred.
The threat to Facua, treading upon, among others, articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a perilous assault, not

not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, fundamental principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore request that the government of Mr. Rajoy rectify the transgression of illegalizing Facua, and I call upon the Commission to guarantee the protection of the
to defend the rights of Spanish consumers and to act against the reduction of rights and functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish Government intends to impose.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to highlight the excellent work of Ms. Macagan, the rapporteur, and also of the other rapporteurs, in reaching this agreement.
agreement at first reading, which was very important since the regulations we had approved in 2010 came into effect and it was necessary to revise them.
not because it was bad legislation—the legislation was very good—but as has been said, recent events, known to all, occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain
a lagoon that needed to be rectified to prevent it from recurring, and specific points of drug surveillance and security after commercialization had to be reinforced.

Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, the holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product that do not renew, withdraw, request the withdrawal of, or suspend the authorization will retain the authorization.
obligation to declare the real reasons and the motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of a drug’s authorization.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all concerned Member States where this medication is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without unduly burdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.

The second significant modification achieved is that all authorized products subject to a post-authorization safety study will be automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Finally, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and therefore this plenary session should approve this proposal.
Thank you very much, President. The agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the member states involved unanimously approved at the IMO.
These seas exhibit a concerning state of acidification.

The required fuels are going to be more expensive, and therefore economic assistance for businesses is anticipated, which is quite reasonable.
But some colleagues have attempted to have the requirements for new fuels also applied to all seas of the European Union.

We would encounter the paradox of a Union country’s environmental problem being resolved by creating a first-order economic problem in the Mediterranean, a region that does not have that problem but does have other environmental issues whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The treaty is very clear.

but not all areas are equally sensitive.

Thank you, Mr. President. I want to reiterate my gratitude to everyone who has made this directive a reality, to the secretariat, to the commissioner, to the rapporteur, to all those I may have forgotten, and to all colleagues who have stood with us.
I want to say to the victims, to all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinctions, that for us they and their families have faces, have names, are real, and precisely in their name.

We will work to ensure this directive does not remain merely a paper exercise, but, with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, whose abilities I have absolutely no doubt, achieves rapid and effective implementation, which is what we all expect and all
citizen.

I believe there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and still want a directive of their own. But I will tell you that the directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victim and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am certain that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When they ask me—and they do ask me in my country—what I do in Europe, then I will be able to say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me great strength to continue working.

I am confident that with support and commitment, not only from those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will, together and with the assistance of the honourable member, bring the victims out of that unjust oblivion.
Colleague Turmes has done admirable work, as pushing forward a regulation like this required the courage of this rapporteur, who has skillfully neutralized numerous and cleverly arranged obstacles.
It has been worth it because energy efficiency and savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should commend significant measures such as the requirement for the renovation of public buildings, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private enterprises.
However, the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs will be of no avail if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that must, in turn, be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives from the regions, the municipalities, and European citizens.
I wish to highlight the participation of these latter.
At present, what is observed is considerable frivolity among authorities and citizens.
Don't we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter people seated on heated sidewalk terraces?
Friend Turnes, we must not spare any effort to save energy.
One must commend the opponent, Aira H. García, for the work she has done and congratulate oneself on the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.

The new quality scheme for agricultural products entails a simplification of the system and a streamlining of existing authorization procedures—and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a significant achievement that the obligation to use the community logo has been included for protected designations of origin and geographical indications, as this enables improved visibility of European productions.
I also believe it is noteworthy that the provisions for protecting quality appeals in bilateral agreements with third countries should be strengthened and a legal basis created for
to defend the logo of the European Union in those third countries, because I genuinely believe that the protection of European products in third countries should be an unwavering objective.

It's unfortunate that this package was somewhat stripped down during the negotiation, and it's a shame, I say again, that the Council isn't here to hear it, because the original quality package that it proposed…
The committee has somewhat overlooked the commercial standards and the offer management by the quality denominations of origin, detached from the agreement and, as I say, leaving it a little hollow.
I believe it is necessary to nurture the stance demonstrated by the Council in these two matters, refusing to listen to the positions of Parliament, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by the appellations of origin should have been defended and was indeed defended within the Common Organisation of the Markets in Agricultural Products.

Thank you, Mr. President. The trade agreement with Central America, Colombia, and Peru is an important agreement, and the safeguard clause—with the amendments we have presented—aims to be easy, agile, and to provide guarantees.

We have proposed amendments to protect European production in accordance with the treaties, and we are establishing security mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the agreement is established.
Protection of the outermost regions is necessary because they do not have diversified crops, due to the economic factor which affects a large number of
jobs, more than 10,000 direct and 35,000 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely affected by unemployment and its specific characteristics.
For example, the Canary banana possesses a significant specificity in agriculture, culture, and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary there, where we are going to establish the agreement, in Central America, Colombia, and Peru, because trade is fundamental to development, and development entails labor rights, sustainability, and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the speaker's work is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, within this framework, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can readily observe.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught: that general laws should be few in number and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must employ all possible clarity.
And Montesquieu consistently insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is to say, we must avoid esoteric jargon, replete with neologisms and unwarranted loanwords, because it generates a pernicious web where traps lie in wait and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves—judges, lawyers—to feel dismayed by our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way of demonstrating respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I have just spent the time, the little time I had, insulting and denigrating from the most absolute ignorance.
ignorance. You know the Spanish Constitution.

What the Vice President, Mr. Vidal Cuadras, has stated is nothing more or less than applying what is stipulated in the Spanish Constitution. Everything else comprises individual and singular assessments that are absolutely irrelevant and which I can respect, but which I disregard.

Thank you, Mr. President. Ladies and gentlemen, there exists an old principle that has passed from the legal realm to the political one: *pacta sunt servanda*. That is to say, agreements are to be kept.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the European Council in June to address the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and these decisions have been positively received—decisions that may break the vicious cycle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as the plans to advance towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irrevocably.
The European Council, observed last week, contains, esteemed members, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions regarding progress towards the Banking Union are satisfactory.
The A27 agreement for the establishment of the supervisory authority is also a positive development. It is finally appropriate to entrust its launch to the Economy Ministers of the Eurozone.
However, he will be permitted to undertake a critical assessment of the biased interpretations that have been made of it in a unilateral manner.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that may distort the mandate entrusted to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we applaud the recounting of matters as agreements that were not even discussed.
It is urgently necessary to advance toward a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also required.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the advantages of the single market are undeniable. Increase in competition, expansion of the supply of products and services.
services, the creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers, and greater protection—still insufficient, and we cannot afford complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist, and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully benefiting from the single market.
Half a year ago, we celebrated the presentation of the 12 priorities to stimulate growth and reinforce citizens’ confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as acknowledged by the Commission in its communication last week.

Distinguished members, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis compels us to be ambitious, to go far beyond, and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment, and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr. President, I too would like to congratulate the speaker and the rest of my colleagues who have worked on this reform very effectively.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and exotic tradable instruments that are linked to derivative instruments and to transactions outside of official markets. All of this with the aim of achieving high returns with great speed.
It is necessary to bring financial operations to a transparent market to guarantee the proper formation of prices and the competitiveness of negotiable products.
Above all, it is essential that the information provided be comprehensible to investors who must have full knowledge to freely consent to the risks they assume.
Transparency is of no use if it is merely a bright flash of light when the complexity of the configuration of negotiable products obscures the understanding of citizens.
I appreciate Mrs. Thyssen’s report because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in political debate is moving in the right direction.
Too frequently we hear the accusation leveled at European institutions for their limited democratic quality.
This is a casual statement, and this is not the occasion to enter into this debate.

Indeed, to emphasize that this Parliament possesses the same legitimacy as any National Parliament, and it is even probable that, with respect to some, it is governed by more transparent rules and furthermore allows greater freedom to its members.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass the filter that this Parliament represents, before their definitive approval and subsequently upon examining their execution and results.

President, 5.3% of the active population works in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, coupled with corporate strategy, generally leads to outsourcing and restructuring of companies.
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting 10 assembly plants and potentially 100,000 workers.

Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term perspective prevails, in which the primary element is gaining competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I have to tell you that on the very same day Ford communicated the suspension of the Heng plant, the Ford company in Valencia was also informed, in the same corporate communication, that its production would be transferred to Germany.

Therefore, for this reason, we believe it to be a general problem of Europe; we believe that the creation of a legal framework at the European level is essential, one that anticipates changes and underscores the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common policy on security and defense.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a distinct European dimension, in contrast to the minority and Eurosceptic factions also represented in this Chamber.
Mr. Danian's report, for which I wish to express my gratitude for his commitment to consensus-building during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
We would like to see these aspects included in a potential revision of the European Defence Strategy.
We have also noted that a strong common policy on security and defense is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is acquiring significant dimensions for our global security.
it is that of cybersecurity and cyber defense, reports that we also debated today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.

In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which Member States are being compelled to reduce their defense budgets, it is precisely when such European protection projects are most needed.
Therefore, it is more important than ever to reinforce the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being heavily challenged today.
I conclude by affirming that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with President Ford Lapui’s project for the December 2013 Council.
Many thanks to the four speakers.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and the Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Having previously accepted the legitimacy of both positions, achieving a balance is now unavoidable.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency’s proposal is, in our judgment, unacceptable.
A cut of €75 billion from the already inevitably limited proposal of the European Commission is sterile and futile.
And it’s not just that. The new direct cuts to agricultural and cohesion policies represent crossing the red line that Spain has established from the beginning of the proceedings.
Honorable members, the time for debating a purported dichotomy between austerity and growth is over.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
With this budget, we get nowhere. Rather, it undermines the waterline.
Distinguished members, it is not possible to achieve a greater Europe with significantly fewer resources, especially if what remains is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply entails the disappearance of growth possibilities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, to whom we owe thanks for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

At this point, in the need of the Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for, the other day in Cádiz, making a forceful declaration of interpretation of the treaties regarding a supposed secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as guardian of the treaties, that if a portion of a Member State secedes as an independent State, it shall be considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the treaty itself shall not affect it in any respect.

I trust, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this may be recorded and that this secure and consistent doctrine of the commission may continue to remain vital for the assurance of all.
